title: New Zealand Stamps Out the Virus. For a Second Time.
first_paragraph: The first time New Zealand thought it had eliminated the coronavirus from its isolated shores, a mysterious outbreak in its largest city shattered any sense of victory over a tenacious foe.

title: ‘It Really Was Abandonment’: Virus Crisis Grips British Universities
first_paragraph: Inside a dormitory now known by students as H.M.P., for Her Majesty’s Prison, trash piled up in shared kitchens. Students washed their clothes in bathroom sinks. Security guards stalked the gates, keeping anyone from leaving or entering.

title: The Pilgrimage Must Go On: Senegal Holds Festival That Could Draw Millions
first_paragraph: All roads to the holy city of Touba were bumper-to-bumper. Buses packed with pilgrims inched along, their roofs piled high with foam mattresses. Tollbooth attendants smiled in greeting and held out ungloved hands for change, all day long.

title: Distrust of China Jumps to New Highs in Democratic Nations
first_paragraph: Xi Jinping celebrates China’s battle against the coronavirus as a success. But in the United States and other wealthy democracies, the pandemic has driven negative views of China to new heights, a survey published on Tuesday showed.

title: Maduro Wins Chance of New Ruling Over Billions in Gold Held in U.K.
first_paragraph: A British court gave another chance to President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela in a tug of war over about $2 billion of gold stored at the Bank of England in a contentious case that pivots on whom Britain recognizes as the South American country’s leader.

title: Pompeo’s Message in Japan: Countering China Is Worth Meeting Face to Face
first_paragraph: For Japan, it was the first time its new prime minister hosted international emissaries. For the United States, it was the first trip to Asia by its top diplomat in more than a year.

title: Contact tracing efforts are restricted to the two days before Trump’s diagnosis.
first_paragraph: Despite almost daily disclosures of new coronavirus infections among President Trump’s close associates, the White House is making little effort to investigate the scope and source of its outbreak.

title: Quino, Creator of Beloved ‘Mafalda’ Cartoon, Dies at 88
first_paragraph: Joaquín Salvador Lavado, the Argentine cartoonist known as Quino who created a comic strip about an irreverent girl named Mafalda whose unique view of daily life and politics made her beloved across Spanish-speaking countries, died on Sept. 30 at his home in Luján de Cuyo, Argentina. He was 88.

title: In U.K.’s Test and Trace: Now You See ’em, Now You Don’t
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s “world beating” test-and-trace program has been dogged by technical glitches, overburdened laboratories and poorly trained contact tracers. Now, add to that a data-entry error more likely to trip up an amateur bookkeeper than the public health service of the world’s sixth-largest economy.

title: China Ramps Up a War of Words, Warning the U.S. of Its Red Lines
first_paragraph: The soldiers run through the forest, through the surf, through smoke and flames, ready to die for the motherland. The video, one of a series that has recently appeared online in China, climaxes with the launch of nine ballistic missiles and a fiery barrage of explosions.

title: Indonesia’s Parliament Approves Jobs Bill, Despite Labor and Environmental Fears
first_paragraph: Indonesia’s Parliament gave final approval Monday to a sweeping jobs-creation bill that would loosen labor and environmental regulations, moves that critics say would harm workers and permit widespread deforestation.

title: Israel’s Coronavirus Lockdown Fuels Protests, Violence and Confusion
first_paragraph: Fractured by internal political conflicts, confusing instructions and a lack of public trust in the government, Israel seems to be fraying further under a second national lockdown as the country struggles to cope with a surge in coronavirus cases and deaths that, relative to the size of the population, are among the worst in the world.

title: The Pressure to Be Perfect Turns Deadly for Celebrities in Japan
first_paragraph: From the outside, Yuko Takeuchi seemed to have a golden life. She had won Japan’s top acting award three times and had recently given birth to her second child. A graceful beauty, she appeared in a box-office favorite last year and advertisements for a top ramen brand.

title: Paris will close its bars and many cafes for at least two weeks starting on Tuesday.
first_paragraph: Bars in Paris will close for two weeks starting on Tuesday, the authorities there announced on Monday, as France tries to stem a surge of coronavirus cases in its capital. The measure will also affect most cafes, which in many cases serve alcohol, but little or no food. Restaurants will be able to remain open if they follow a strict health protocol.

title: ‘Keep Calm and Carry On’ May Not Work in a Time of Pandemic
first_paragraph: During a recent visit to a private London hospital, I was horrified to encounter a delivery man wheeling in a load of supplies without wearing a face mask. An orderly in blue scrubs stood inside the elevator, three feet from me, with his mask draped around his chin.

title: Pope Criticizes Lack of Unity in World’s Response to Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Pope Francis criticized the failures of global cooperation in response to the coronavirus pandemic in a document released on Sunday that underscores the priorities of his pontificate.

title: President Trump, undergoing an experimental antiviral treatment, spends a third day in the hospital.
first_paragraph: President Trump entered his third day in the hospital on Sunday after contracting the coronavirus and falling ill last week, even as confusing and contradictory accounts about his medical condition added to the national sense of uncertainty and concern for the 74-year-old president’s well-being.

title: Mike Pompeo cuts visits to South Korea and Mongolia from his Asia trip.
first_paragraph: As President Trump remains hospitalized with Covid-19, Secretary of State Mike Pompeo will cut short a trip to Asia this week, canceling stops in South Korea and Mongolia but continuing with a visit to Japan.

title: Despite Crises, India Fixes Its Gaze on a Bollywood Tragedy
first_paragraph: A rising young movie star meets a tragic end. His family blames his death on his glamorous girlfriend. As she sits in jail, her friends proclaiming her innocence, the police hint at a shadowy network of money laundering and illegal drugs deep within the world of show business.

title: Data shows fewer Afghan women than men get Covid-19. That’s bad news.
first_paragraph: a discrepancy that experts say is most likely the result of women being shut out of the health care system and the public sphere.

title: Chris Christie, who helped Trump prepare for the debate, has the virus.
first_paragraph: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey who for several days this week helped the president prepare for the debate, said he has tested positive for the coronavirus.

title: Contact Tracing, Key to Reining In the Virus, Falls Flat in the West
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus stampeded across Europe and the United States this spring, governments made their depleted citizens a tantalizing promise: Soon, legions of disease detectives would hunt down anyone exposed to the virus, confining them to their homes and letting everyone else get on with their lives.

title: India’s Covid-19 Death Toll Passes 100,000
first_paragraph: More than 100,000 people in India have died from the coronavirus, the government said on Saturday, even as officials plan to lift more restrictions in hopes of reviving the crippled economy.

title: Trump says he feels better, but his chief of staff says he is ‘still not on a clear path to a full recovery.’
first_paragraph: President Trump’s vital signs were “very concerning” over the last day and he is not out of danger, the White House chief of staff said on Saturday, contradicting a rosier picture painted by the president’s doctors on television just minutes before.

title: Tight New Restrictions in Parts of Quebec as Cases Rise Again
first_paragraph: The arrival of autumn has brought along the predicted rebound of coronavirus infections, at least in Quebec and Ontario.

title: World Reacts to Trump’s Diagnosis With Shock, Unease and Some Derision
first_paragraph: Some pointed to the irony of it. Others offered well wishes. More than a few said it was just deserts.

title: Trump Tests Positive for Coronavirus, and the World Shudders
first_paragraph: President Trump’s disclosure that he had been infected by the coronavirus sent a shudder around the world on Friday, drawing sympathy from leaders who have grappled with the pandemic in their own countries and more pointed responses from critics who noted Mr. Trump’s cavalier handling of the threat.

title: Trump’s positive cause global markets to tumble.
first_paragraph: Global markets dropped early Friday after President Trump said that he and the first lady had tested positive for the coronavirus.

title: Trump and first lady test positive for the virus.
first_paragraph: President Trump said early Friday that he and his wife, Melania, had tested positive for the coronavirus, throwing the nation’s leadership into uncertainty and escalating the crisis posed by a pandemic that has already killed more than 207,000 Americans and devastated the economy.

title: Covid-19 Upends South Korea’s Thanksgiving, and Its Rituals
first_paragraph: Once a year for the past three decades, the Joo brothers have traveled back to their hometown from South Korea’s capital to mark the Chuseok holiday.

title: Indonesia’s Stimulus Plan Draws Fire From Environmentalists and Unions
first_paragraph: Indonesia’s Parliament is on the verge of approving a sweeping coronavirus stimulus package that opponents charge would undermine worker protections and permit widespread destruction of the country’s rainforests.

title: A top Trump aide has tested positive for the virus.
first_paragraph: One of President Trump’s most senior advisers has tested positive for the coronavirus, three people familiar with the matter said Thursday night.

title: After 2 Years of Paralysis, Belgium Forms a (Very Fragile) Government
first_paragraph: For nearly two years, Belgium has been without a formal government, leaving a country that was already divided by language and politics to endure a pandemic with lame-duck caretakers wielding emergency powers.

title: On China’s National Day, Hong Kong Police Quash Protests
first_paragraph: One year ago, China’s National Day on Oct. 1 was a day of protest and turmoil in Hong Kong. Demonstrators set fires and blockaded streets. The police responded with tear gas and pepper spray. One officer shot a young demonstrator with a live bullet.

title: Fans celebrate the Stanley Cup champions, well outside the N.H.L.’s pandemic bubble.
first_paragraph: The Tampa Bay Lightning won the National Hockey League’s top trophy on Monday from within the confines of a 24/7 pandemic bubble in western Canada, and without any fans in the arena to watch.

title: The Carnival Parade Is Canceled, and Rio Is Reeling
first_paragraph: For more than a century, Rio de Janeiro’s carnival has been an irrepressible force, unstoppable by wars, disease, labor strikes or political repression.

title: Woman Dies in Delhi After Gang Rape, Fueling Outrage Again in India
first_paragraph: A teenager from a north Indian village who was dragged from a field and raped by a group of men died of her injuries at a hospital in New Delhi on Tuesday, triggering nationwide outrage again after years of what experts describe as a gang rape epidemic in India.

title: Russians Were Urged to Return to Normal Life. Except for Putin.
first_paragraph: The officials from a secretive Russian security force seemed to know exactly what they wanted when they reached out to Olga Izranova’s company last spring.

title: In Madrid, Covid-19 Resurgence Divides Rich and Poor
first_paragraph: Every weekday morning, Jorge Sánchez leaves home in Puente de Vallecas, one of the poorest and most densely populated areas of Madrid, and drives 10 miles to his job as a gardener tending a public park in an affluent district of the city.

title: For Boris Johnson, a Grim Premiership That No One Foresaw
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson likes to style himself as a buccaneer, waving a cutlass and thumbing his nose at convention as he leads Britain into an uncharted future. These days, however, he looks more like a latter-day Captain Bligh, grimly confronting one mutiny after another.

title: Vilified Early Over Lax Virus Strategy, Sweden Seems to Have Scourge Controlled
first_paragraph: The scene at Norrsken House Stockholm, a co-working space, oozed with radical normalcy: Young, turtleneck-wearing hipsters schmoozed in the coffee corner. Others chatted freely away, at times quite near each other, in cozy conference rooms. Face masks were nowhere to be seen.

title: In France, Southerners Grumble at Virus Restrictions From Up North
first_paragraph: The longstanding antagonism that pits Paris, the occasionally overbearing French capital, against Marseille, its sunnier, more rambunctious rival on the Mediterranean coast, has found a new battleground: the coronavirus.

title: As Covid-19 Closes Schools, the World’s Children Go to Work
first_paragraph: Every morning in front of the Devaraj Urs public housing apartment blocks on the outskirts of the city of Tumakuru, a swarm of children pours into the street.

title: There’s Gold in Them Thar Braes
first_paragraph: As a late afternoon mist rolled in over hills carpeted with purple heather, Alan Popovich stood knee deep in a fast-flowing river, weary but undaunted despite searching all day in the water without success.

title: In Melbourne, Springtime Ushers in a New Sense of Hope
first_paragraph: There are blossoms on the trees in Melbourne and days of cold rain and blustering wind, but also days of sweet-smelling breezes and warm sunshine. This has been a hard year for my hometown, which is still undergoing one of the world’s strictest and longest lockdowns because of the pandemic.

title: Pandemic Will ‘Take Our Women 10 Years Back’ in the Workplace
first_paragraph: As if working mothers did not have enough to worry about, experts are now sounding the alarm that progress toward gender equality may be the latest in a long list of casualties of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: ‘I Feel Sorry for Americans’: A Baffled World Watches the U.S.
first_paragraph: Myanmar is a poor country struggling with open ethnic warfare and a coronavirus outbreak that could overload its broken hospitals. That hasn’t stopped its politicians from commiserating with a country they think has lost its way.

title: Stranded Overseas, Thousands Beg Australia to Let Them Come Home
first_paragraph: Alison Richards, a 38-year-old graphic designer, had been living in Britain for five years when she decided to move home to Australia. Then she got sick with Covid-19 and lost her job.

title: Kim Jong-un Offers South Korea Rare Apology for Killing of Official
first_paragraph: North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, offered a rare apology on Friday for the killing of a South Korean government official at sea by soldiers from the North, South Korea said.

title: Famine Emerges as U.N. Theme, Crystallized by Yemen Disaster
first_paragraph: The coronavirus scourge is a prevailing theme at this year’s United Nations General Assembly, forcing the gathering to be conducted largely online. But the pandemic is also fueling another crisis preoccupying the organization and humanitarian groups: the strong prospect of famine in some of the world’s most destitute places.

title: Hong Kong Police Arrest Activist for Violating 2019 Mask Ban
first_paragraph: Joshua Wong, one of Hong Kong’s most visible pro-democracy activists, has been arrested multiple times for taking part in antigovernment protests that erupted over the past year and roiled the city for months before the coronavirus pandemic hit.

title: As Virus Cases Surge in Europe, Hospitalizations Lag. But for How Long?
first_paragraph: In Munich, normally brimming with boisterous crowds for Oktoberfest this month, the authorities just banned gatherings of more than five people. In Marseille, France, all bars and restaurants will be closed next Monday. And in London, where the government spent weeks urging workers to return to the city’s empty skyscrapers, it is now asking them to work from home.

title: Israel Tightens Holiday Lockdown, Restricting Prayers and Protests
first_paragraph: Warning that his country could be approaching “the edge of the abyss,” Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu imposed an even tighter lockdown than the one he announced last week to limit the spread of the coronavirus in Israel, which now has the highest rate of new cases per capita in the world.

title: Even as Virus Surges, Hungary Forges Ahead With Super Cup Soccer Game
first_paragraph: Two top European soccer clubs, Bayern Munich and Sevilla, faced off as scheduled in front of thousands of fans in Budapest on Thursday night despite a sharp rise in coronavirus cases in Hungary.

title: A Manila Barbershop’s Mirrors Reflect the Pain of the Pandemic
first_paragraph: For 20 years, amid military coups, typhoons and terrorist attacks, Rollie Magalona’s clients have streamed into his barbershop in Metro Manila for more than just a cut and a shave.

title: North Korea Accused of Shooting and Burning South Korean Defector
first_paragraph: A South Korean official trying to defect to North Korea was killed by troops in the North who set his body on fire for fear he might be carrying the coronavirus, South Korean officials said on Thursday.

title: The Nose Needed for This Coronavirus Test Isn’t Yours. It’s a Dog’s.
first_paragraph: Travelers arriving at Helsinki’s airport are being offered a voluntary coronavirus test that takes 10 seconds with no uncomfortable nasal swab needed. And the test is done by a dog.

title: China’s Pledge to Be Carbon Neutral by 2060: What It Means
first_paragraph: Environmentalists have welcomed the pledge by China’s leader, Xi Jinping, to speed up reductions in emissions in the world’s top-polluting nation and reach carbon neutrality by 2060.

title: In the Epicenter of Mexico’s Epicenter, Feeling Like a ‘Trapped Animal’
first_paragraph: The man in the vegetable stall next to Christopher Arriaga’s died first. A longtime customer was next, then another. A few days later, an elderly carrot vendor got sick and died within the week.

title: A Somber Boris Johnson Offers Britain a New Plan to Halt the Virus
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has always looked for the silver lining in Britain’s response to the pandemic. Last spring, he promised to “send coronavirus packing” in 12 weeks. In the summer, he cajoled people to return to their offices and restaurants, even offering to subsidize their meals.

title: U.N. General Assembly: China Calls on World to Reject Politicization of Covid
first_paragraph: The presidents of the United States and China squared off in their speeches to the annual General Assembly on Tuesday, punctuating a superpower rivalry that the leader of the 193-member organization, Secretary-General António Guterres, has called a great global risk.

title: In Italy Elections, Salvini Coalition Fails to Take Tuscan Prize
first_paragraph: A center-right coalition led by the anti-immigrant League party of Matteo Salvini, the nationalist former deputy prime minister of Italy, made gains in regional elections on Monday, but failed to take the day’s biggest prize: the important region of Tuscany.

title: U.K.’s Boris Johnson Orders Pubs and Restaurants to Close Early
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain announced plans to impose new restrictions on nightlife, including the forced early closure of pubs and restaurants in England, as he ramps up efforts to curb a rising tide of coronavirus infections.

title: U.N. Assembly, With Very Few Assembled, Marks 75th Year
first_paragraph: With nods to its founding from the ashes of World War II, the United Nations officially celebrated the organization’s 75th year Monday in a somber and largely virtual event streamed on the internet because of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: At the U.N., a General Assembly Like No Other
first_paragraph: The General Assembly will begin its annual speeches by world leaders on Tuesday, but on Monday it held a separate and largely virtual gathering to commemorate the passage of the United Nations into its fourth quarter-century.

title: A TV Drama on China’s Fight With Covid-19 Draws Ire Over Its Depiction of Women
first_paragraph: The scene came seven minutes into a new Chinese-government-sponsored television drama, so short that it would have been easy to miss: The head of a bus company in Wuhan, the city where the coronavirus outbreak began, asks his drivers if they are willing to make emergency runs during the city’s lockdown. A line of volunteers forms. None are women.

title: Russia Is Slow to Administer Virus Vaccine Despite Kremlin’s Approval
first_paragraph: More than a month after becoming the first country to approve a coronavirus vaccine, Russia has yet to administer it to a large population outside a clinical trial, health officials and outside experts say.

title: In South Korea, Covid-19 Comes With Another Risk: Online Bullies
first_paragraph: The scandal that riveted South Korea’s online busybodies began when Kim Ji-seon checked into a beachside condominium in February. A 29-year-old office worker planning a June wedding, she had nothing more salacious in mind than meeting with members of her church to organize a youth program.

title: Peru President, Martín Vizcarra, Survives Impeachment Vote
first_paragraph: President Martín Vizcarra of Peru survived an impeachment vote on Friday, ending a congressional battle which had threatened to plunge the country into a constitutional crisis amid a devastating pandemic.

title: On Ukraine’s Border, the Coronavirus Ends a Hasidic Pilgrimage
first_paragraph: Thousands of Hasidic pilgrims who set out to celebrate the Jewish New Year at the grave in Ukraine of a revered rabbi started heading home on Friday, after being prevented from entering from Belarus due to coronavirus travel restrictions.

title: Britain Scrambles to Avoid a Second Lockdown
first_paragraph: Local shutdowns are creeping across England. A vaunted testing system is on the verge of collapse. And Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain is contemplating temporary closures of restaurants and pubs to corral a second surge of the coronavirus that threatens to land Europe’s worst-affected country in the same predicament it faced this spring.

title: Israelis Prepare to Celebrate the Year’s Holiest Days Under Lockdown
first_paragraph: As Israelis prepare to celebrate the holiest days on the Jewish calendar under a fresh lockdown, organizing prayer services is proving to be more of a mathematical brainteaser than a spiritual exercise.

title: China, Seeking a Friend in Europe, Finds Rising Anger and Frustration
first_paragraph: After rebuking a senior Czech lawmaker for visiting Taiwan this month, the Chinese foreign minister, Wang Yi, received an obscenity-laced public letter that punctuated just how far China’s standing in Europe has fallen.

title: On This Island, Everyone Knows Your Name (if You Have Covid-19)
first_paragraph: The man taking the last drag of his cigarette in the sweltering heat outside his convenience store in Volissos, a village on the Greek island of Chios, was clear: No mask, no shopping.

title: Afghan Migrants Charged With Arson in Fires that Destroyed Lesbos Camp

title: Virus Strands Hasidic Pilgrims on Ukraine-Belarus Border

title: As Second Wave of Virus Builds, U.K. Enters New Testing Crisis

title: U.S. Marine Pardoned for Killing Transgender Woman Is Deported From Philippines

title: North Korean Propaganda Gets a YouTube Makeover: Fewer Parades, More Pizza

title: Pandemic Collides With Europe’s Migrant Crisis to Set Off a Calamity in Greece
first_paragraph: The thousands of asylum seekers crammed into Europe’s largest refugee camp, on the Greek island of Lesbos, had for years bridled at their squalid conditions and the endless delays in resolving their fates. Then came the coronavirus and its strict containment measures, which compounded their misery.

title: Summer Jet-Setters Turned Sardinia Into a Virus Hot Spot
first_paragraph: The allure of the turquoise waters, extravagant villas and exclusive dance clubs of the Emerald Coast of Sardinia proved stronger than ever in August, as Italian tourists hungry for virus-free air mingled with regulars of the international party circuit hopping across from places like the Spanish island of Ibiza and Mykonos in the Aegean Sea.

title: Sitting in Silence With 5,000 Fans: The New Sound of Japanese Sports
first_paragraph: As the players drove the ball down the field, I suddenly heard the distinct crinkle of a plastic bag a full four rows in front of me, where a man was pulling out a chicken drumstick to eat.

title: ‘The Lockdown Killed My Father’: Farmer Suicides Add to India’s Virus Misery

title: As Brexit Deadlines Loom, the Posturing and Bickering Flare Again

title: Hong Kong Police Block Protests Over Delayed Election
first_paragraph: Thousands of police officers in riot gear filled the streets of Hong Kong on Sunday, stifling efforts to protest the postponement of legislative elections and China’s imposition of a national security law that gives the authorities sweeping new powers to pursue critics.

title: When Learning Is Really Remote: Students Climb Trees and Travel Miles for a Cell Signal

first_paragraph: It was a perfect portrait of the delicate relationship between the Mexican president and his protégée.

title: BBC Lost a Battle Over British Songs, and the War Is Far From Over

title: ‘Here We Go Again’: A Second Virus Wave Grips Spain

title: Pranab Mukherjee, Indispensable Man of Indian Politics, Dies at 84

title: Nyameka Goniwe, 69, Dies; Sought Justice in Her Husband’s Killing

title: Berlin Police Halt March Against Coronavirus Restrictions, Saying Protesters Risked Spreading Disease
first_paragraph: Thousands of Germans angered over restrictions intended to control the coronavirus marched in Berlin on Saturday, but the police dispersed them after an hour because many were violating the very social-distancing rules championed by Chancellor Angela Merkel that they say threaten their rights and livelihoods.

title: As Coronavirus Reappears in Italy, Migrants Become a Target for Politicians
first_paragraph: As the summer vacation season draws to a close in Italy, a flare-up of Covid-19 cases is fueling a surge in anti-immigrant sentiment, even though the government says that migrants are just a small part of the problem.

title: India’s Covid Outbreak Is Now the World’s Fastest-Growing
first_paragraph: India now has the fastest-growing coronavirus caseload of any country in the world, reporting more than 75,000 new infections per day.

title: A Doctor Asks: Is Covid Scaring Us Away From Our Humanity?
first_paragraph: Soren Kierkegaard wrote that “Life can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards.” I wonder how this time of Covid will appear in retrospect.

title: E.U. Trade Chief Quits, a Casualty of Dinner That Flouted Virus Rules
first_paragraph: Phil Hogan, the influential trade commissioner for the European Union, resigned Wednesday night over breaches to coronavirus guidelines during a recent dinner with lawmakers and other public figures in his native Ireland.

title: Schools Can Reopen, Germany Finds, but Expect a ‘Roller Coaster’
first_paragraph: On the Monday after summer vacation, Dirk Kwee was as nervous as he had ever been in 31 years of teaching. For the first time since the pandemic hit, all 900 students at his Berlin school were back, bursting with excitement.

title: Gaza Under Lockdown After First Local Cases of Virus
first_paragraph: Just as a graduation for 400 students was breaking up on Monday night in the blockaded Gaza Strip, a university official rushed to the stage of the brightly lit soccer stadium and took the microphone to address the crowd of Palestinian families, few wearing masks.

title: Outspoken Atheist, Arrested in Nigeria for Blasphemy, Hasn’t Been Seen Since
first_paragraph: Amina Ahmed knew her atheist husband was taking enormous risks with some of his Facebook posts criticizing Christianity and Islam in Nigeria, a deeply religious country.

title: China Locks Down Xinjiang to Fight Covid-19, Angering Residents
first_paragraph: First came the notices that Chinese officials had declared a “wartime” state. Then the authorities started going door to door, sealing off apartments and warning residents to stay inside.

title: ‘GolfGate’ Dinner in Ireland Sparks Political Backlash
first_paragraph: Close to the rugged Atlantic coast, the Station House Hotel in the Irish town of Clifden offers well-heeled guests a stay that will “live in your memories forever.” But right now, that slogan seems more a threat than a promise for some of Ireland’s political leaders.

title: Africa Celebrates the End of the Wild Poliovirus (but Not the End of All Polio)
first_paragraph: Africa is set to announce that it has stamped out wild poliovirus after a three-decade campaign against a disease that once paralyzed 75,000 children on the continent every year.

title: Dancing Ban Aimed at Young People Breaks the Rhythm of Many Older Italians
first_paragraph: Raffaele Leardini, 72, slipped on his pink linen shirt, buttoned it up to the middle of his chest, combed back his hair and set off on Thursday with his wife to Caribe, their favorite outdoor dance hall. When they arrived, they found the club open but the dance floor sealed off with red and white tape.

title: A Lawyer’s Tweets Put India’s Supreme Court on Trial and Him at Risk of Imprisonment
first_paragraph: First, the firebrand lawyer wrote a one-sentence tweet opining about the Indian Supreme Court’s role in eroding freedoms in the world’s largest democracy. Two days later, he tweeted a photo of the court’s chief justice astride a Harley-Davidson owned by a political ally of the country’s powerful prime minister.

title: At Least 14 Killed After Suicide Bombers Hit Philippines
first_paragraph: Two powerful explosions set off by two suicide bombers ripped through heavily populated areas of a southern Philippine island on Monday, killing at least 14 people and wounding 75 others in a known stronghold of the extremist group Abu Sayyaf.

title: Belarus Protests Test Limits of Lukashenko’s Brutal, One-Man Rule
first_paragraph: He jokes about running a dictatorship. He makes his generals salute his teenage son, who shares his penchant for dressing in military uniforms. He commands a brutal security service that makes people disappear. And when Covid-19 arrived, he told his people to play hockey, drive tractors and not worry about it.

title: Russia, Expecting Plaudits for Vaccine, Is Miffed by Its Cool Reception
first_paragraph: It was with great fanfare that President Vladimir V. Putin and other officials announced this month that a billion doses of a Russian vaccine for the new coronavirus would soon be rolled out, supposedly putting an end to the worst pandemic in a century.

title: In China, Where the Pandemic Began, Life Is Starting to Look … Normal
first_paragraph: In Shanghai, restaurants and bars in many neighborhoods are teeming with crowds. In Beijing, thousands of students are heading back to campus for the fall semester. In Wuhan, where the coronavirus emerged eight months ago, water parks and night markets are packed elbow to elbow, buzzing like before.

title: Crocs and Irukandji: A World Away From the Coronavirus Pandemic. Almost.
first_paragraph: For the past few weeks, I have worried more about being stung by a deadly Irukandji jellyfish or attacked by a crocodile, rather than contracting the coronavirus.

title: ‘A Bit Surreal’: The Lonely Plight of the Great Barrier Reef
first_paragraph: Diving beneath the ocean, Russell Hosp swam toward the limestone bed of the Great Barrier Reef, where he reattached bits of blue staghorn coral. With tourists gone, he was filling the void with this small act of conservation, which took his mind off the uncertain future on land.

title: Kenya’s Health Workers, Unprotected and Falling Ill, Walk Off Job
first_paragraph: Doctors in public hospitals say they have not been paid, some for as long as six months. They’re furious that they’ve been given faulty protective gear, or none at all. Hundreds of government health workers have fallen sick with the coronavirus, and yet many say their medical insurance was cut in July, just when hospitals became overwhelmed with cases.

title: U.K. Exam Chaos Prompts Stampede for College Places
first_paragraph: The calls to Newcastle University started early this week, flooding in at the rate of 1,500 in a day. At Reading University, staff were forced to set up a makeshift phone bank in the library. Durham University, facing overwhelming demand for places in September’s freshman class, offered a cash reward to some young people if they deferred their education for a year.

title: With Coronavirus Cases Surging, Europe Braces for New Phase in Pandemic
first_paragraph: For all of the challenges in controlling the spread of the coronavirus, Europe’s initial strategy was relatively straightforward: nearly universal, strictly enforced lockdowns.

title: Xi Declares War on Food Waste, and China Races to Tighten Its Belt
first_paragraph: Chinese regulators are calling out livestreamers who binge-eat for promoting excessive consumption. A school said it would bar students from applying for scholarships if their daily leftovers exceeded a set amount. A restaurant placed electronic scales at its entrance for customers to weigh themselves to avoid ordering too much.

title: After Covid, China’s Leaders Face New Challenges From Flooding
first_paragraph: Having brought the coronavirus pandemic largely under control, China’s leaders are now struggling with a surge of crippling floods that have killed hundreds of people and displaced millions across the central and southwestern parts of the country.

title: In South Korea’s New Covid-19 Outbreak, Religion and Politics Collide
first_paragraph: For months, the red-brick church in a rundown neighborhood of Seoul, the South Korean capital, has attracted thousands of politically active conservative Christians, all united in the belief that their country is falling into a godless communist hell ​under the leadership of its liberal president, Moon Jae-in.

title: North Korea’s Leader Had Big Economic Plans. He Admits They’ve Failed.
first_paragraph: Back in 2016, North Korea’s freshly minted leader, Kim Jong-un, held the country’s first ruling Workers’ Party’s congress in three decades and laid out an ambitious five-year economic plan to build what he called a “great socialist country” by 2020.

title: Local Officials in China Hid Coronavirus Dangers From Beijing, U.S. Agencies Find
first_paragraph: Trump administration officials have tried taking a political sledgehammer to China over the coronavirus pandemic, asserting that the Chinese Communist Party covered up the initial outbreak and allowed the virus to spread around the globe.

title: South Africa’s Big Coronavirus Aid Effort Tainted by Corruption
first_paragraph: Contracts are being doled out to family members. Food parcels have gone missing. And funds meant for unemployment insurance are making their way into the pockets of political cronies.

title: Venezuela Deploys Security Forces in Coronavirus Crackdown
first_paragraph: Venezuelan officials are denouncing people who may have come into contact with the coronavirus as “bioterrorists” and urging their neighbors to report them. The government is detaining and intimidating doctors and experts who question the president’s policies on the virus.

title: Beaten Back, the Coronavirus Regains Strength in France
first_paragraph: As the two women sat in deck chairs enjoying the last rays of sunshine near the Canal de l’Ourcq in Paris on Sunday evening, nearby loudspeakers jolted them with a reminder that they were in a new mask-mandatory zone.

title: In New Jersey, Tanzania, Peru, TV Lessons Replace Online Learning
first_paragraph: In a hillside shantytown of Lima, Peru, Delia Huamani’s school day starts not with the bustle of classmates, but with the flicker of a television. With physical schools closed indefinitely, she gets her lessons at home, from the country’s brand-new library of slickly made educational broadcasts.

title: New Zealand Election Delayed Amid New Coronavirus Outbreak
first_paragraph: New Zealand on Monday said it would postpone its national election by four weeks as a cluster of new coronavirus cases continued to spread through the city of Auckland despite a lockdown.

title: The Israel-U.A.E. Deal and the Beirut Blast Both Box in Iran
first_paragraph: Iran’s foreign minister flew to Beirut last week to bolster Lebanon and Hezbollah, the Iranian-backed militia and political group that plays a powerful role in the government. Both the militia and the government had been caught in a ferocious public backlash over the explosion that destroyed much of the city.

title: Protests Grow in Thailand, Where Speaking Out Can Be Perilous
first_paragraph: They gathered at a monument celebrating Thai democracy. They raised their hands in defiance below a giant image of the king dressed in coronation regalia.

title: South Korea Warns of Another Covid-19 Outbreak Tied to a Church
first_paragraph: Health officials in South Korea reported 279 new coronavirus cases on Sunday, warning of a resurgence of infections, many linked to a church that has vocally opposed President Moon Jae-in.

title: Coronavirus Crisis Has Made Brazil an Ideal Vaccine Laboratory
first_paragraph: The chaotic response to the coronavirus in Brazil, where it has killed more than 105,000 people, made the country’s experience a cautionary tale that many around the world have watched with alarm.

title: Mothers, Babies Stranded in Ukraine Surrogacy Industry
first_paragraph: Tears streamed down Yevhenia Troyan’s face as her flight took off from Northern Cyprus, one of the odd corners of Europe where Ukrainian surrogacy agencies have set up shop.

title: Parents, Students and Teachers Give Britain a Failing Grade Over Exam Results
first_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of teenagers in England tore open envelopes this week bearing the results of their A-levels, comprehensive exams that are supposed to assess the quality of their secondary education and serve as a barometer for college entrance.

title: As Britain Climbs Out of an Economic Pit, Tough Questions Loom
first_paragraph: To understand why Britain has spiraled into the deepest recession of its modern history, go for a stroll in central London, no longer a ghost town but still a shadow of its once-bustling self.

title: New Zealand Beat the Virus Once. Can It Do It Again?
first_paragraph: As the week began, New Zealanders were celebrating 100 days without community spread of the coronavirus, drinking at pubs, packing stadiums and hugging friends.

title: U.S. Coronavirus Death Toll Reflects Sun Belt Outbreaks
first_paragraph: Officials across the United States reported more than 1,470 deaths on Wednesday, the highest single-day total yet in August, according to a New York Times database, and a reflection of the continued toll of the early-summer case surge in Sun Belt states.

title: Russia Approves Coronavirus Vaccine Before Completing Tests
first_paragraph: Russia has become the first country in the world to approve a vaccine for the coronavirus, President Vladimir V. Putin announced on Tuesday, though global health authorities say the vaccine has yet to complete critical, late-stage clinical trials to determine its safety and effectiveness.

title: England’s Flawed Virus Contact Tracing Will Be Revamped
first_paragraph: England will overhaul its faltering coronavirus contact-tracing system, the government said on Monday, shifting some control from private contractors to local public health teams and cutting the jobs of thousands of call center workers who had complained of having no one to call.

title: Trump’s Order on Coronavirus Relief Alarms Governors as Stimulus Talks Stall
first_paragraph: Governors across the United States struggled on Monday with how to make good on President Trump’s order that their economically battered states deliver billions more in unemployment benefits to jobless residents.

title: ‘I’d Rather Stay Home and Die’
first_paragraph: A gray Suzuki stopped outside the General Hospital of Mexico and deposited a heaving Victor Bailón at the entrance. He had refused to come to the hospital for days, convinced that doctors were killing coronavirus patients. By the time he hobbled into the triage area and collapsed on the floor, it was too late.

title: As U.S. and Taiwan Celebrate a Bond, China Responds With Screaming Jets
first_paragraph: The United States’ top health official lauded Taiwan’s democracy and its response to the coronavirus. Taiwan’s president hailed the island’s growing economic and public health ties with the United States.

title: When Covid-19 Hit, Many Elderly Were Left to Die
first_paragraph: Shirley Doyen was exhausted. The Christalain nursing home, which she ran with her brother in an affluent neighborhood in Brussels, was buckling from Covid-19. Eight residents had died in three weeks. Some staff members had only gowns and goggles from Halloween doctor costumes for protection.

title: Bolivia Under Blockade as Protesters Choke Access to Cities
first_paragraph: Antigovernment protesters in Bolivia blockaded some of the country’s main roads this past week to challenge the delay of general elections and rebuke the government’s poor response to the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Canada Has Placed Its First Vaccine Order, but Don’t Expect a ‘Silver Bullet’
first_paragraph: For Canadians anxiously craving an inoculation against the coronavirus, this week brought both optimism and words of sobering caution.

title: As U.N. Warns of Catastrophe, Lebanon’s Leaders Debate Cause of Blast
first_paragraph: As rescue workers continued to comb the debris for survivors of the deadly explosion in the port of Beirut, and as the United Nations warned that Lebanon faced a humanitarian catastrophe, the nation’s leaders debated the possible cause of the blast but provided little new information.

title: Sri Lanka Election Hands Rajapaksa Family a Bigger Slice of Control
first_paragraph: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s governing party won a majority of Sri Lanka’s parliamentary seats, the Election Commission announced Friday, bringing the president a step closer in his quest to amend the Constitution and expand his executive power.

title: After a Lull, the Number of Migrants Trying to Enter the U.S. Has Soared
first_paragraph: Illegal migration along the southwest border of the United States has surged after a period of stagnation, as economic hardship, made worse by the pandemic, has driven thousands northward seeking work.

title: Dozens Charged in Hong Kong for Taking Part in Tiananmen Protest
first_paragraph: Two dozen democracy advocates in Hong Kong were charged on Thursday with taking part in an annual vigil honoring the victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests, the latest sign of the aggressive clampdown on dissent in the semiautonomous Chinese territory.

title: It’s Never Too Late to Pursue a Dream, a Graduate Says. He Can Back It Up.
first_paragraph: Six weeks shy of his birthday, Giuseppe Paternò fulfilled the dream of a lifetime: He got a university degree.

title: Hiroshima 75th Anniversary: Preserving Survivors’ Message of Peace
first_paragraph: The hibakusha, as the survivors of the atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki are known in Japan, have achieved a powerful feat of alchemy, transforming their nightmarish memories of the blasts and their aftermath into a visceral force for promoting a world free of nuclear arms.

title: Kenya’s Unusual Solution to the School Problem: Cancel the Year and Start Over
first_paragraph: For Esther Adhiambo, this year was supposed to be a year of endings and new beginnings. She was expecting to complete high school, enroll in a university and get a job to help her single mother, who runs a small tailoring business in Nairobi’s Mathare slum.

title: Welcome Back to Germany. Now Take Your Free Virus Test.
first_paragraph: When she returned to Germany last week from a vacation in Serbia, one of the first things Snjezana Kirstein did was to stop at a pop-up coronavirus testing center at Berlin’s Tegel Aiport.

title: U.S. Health Secretary to Visit Taiwan, in a Move Likely to Anger Beijing
first_paragraph: The United States’ top health official, Alex M. Azar II, will lead a delegation on a trip to Taiwan, a rare high-level visit to the island by an American official that is likely to further fray ties between Beijing and Washington.

title: Poor and Desperate, Pakistani Hindus Accept Islam to Get By
first_paragraph: The Hindus performed the prayer rituals awkwardly in supplication to their new, single god, as they prepared to leave their many deities behind them. Their lips stumbled over Arabic phrases that, once recited, would seal their conversion to Islam. The last words uttered, the men and boys were then circumcised.

title: Trump’s Syria Sanctions ‘Cannot Solve the Problem,’ Critics Say
first_paragraph: The Trump administration has embarked on its toughest round of economic sanctions against Syria, intending to break President Bashar al-Assad’s reign over the country and stop a civil war that has claimed over half a million lives.

title: When Covid Subsided, Israel Reopened Its Schools. It Didn’t Go Well.
first_paragraph: As the United States and other countries anxiously consider how to reopen schools, Israel, one of the first countries to do so, illustrates the dangers of moving too precipitously.

title: ‘I Am Scared’: Italian Sex Workers Face Poverty and Illness in the Pandemic
first_paragraph: When the mayor of Modica, a Sicilian town known for its chocolates and churches, learned that a sex worker in the area had tested positive for the coronavirus, he immediately started to worry about an outbreak.

title: Taking a Spear Into the Sea, and Washing Anxiety Away
first_paragraph: Emma Shearman held her speargun and focused on her breathing. In, out, relax, she thought. Deep and steady, as rhythmic as the waves.

title: Russia Sets Mass Vaccination for October After Shortened Trial
first_paragraph: Russia plans to launch a nationwide vaccination campaign in October with a coronavirus vaccine that has yet to complete clinical trials, raising international concern about the methods the country is using to compete in the global race to inoculate the public.

title: Ethiopian Workers Are Forced to Return Home, Some With Coronavirus
first_paragraph: Unemployed and shunned as possible coronavirus carriers, Ethiopian migrant laborers are returning home by the thousands, placing a huge strain on Ethiopia’s poorly equipped medical system.

title: Indian Billionaires Bet Big on Head Start in Coronavirus Vaccine Race
first_paragraph: In early May, an extremely well-sealed steel box arrived at the cold room of the Serum Institute of India, the world’s largest vaccine maker.

title: ‘Cocktails and Masks Don’t Really Go Together’
first_paragraph: When Nest, a cramped Moscow cocktail lounge, reopened for business in late June after more than two months of lockdown, it offered free masks and antiseptic lotion at the entrance to help calm any fears drinkers might have about sitting just inches from each other around tiny round tables.

title: Canada’s Key Role in Creating a Once Awaited Vaccine
first_paragraph: Canadians don’t have to go back to 1918 and the start of the Spanish flu pandemic to find an analogy to today. For decades, waves of polio outbreaks gripped the country with fear, death and uncertainty, as recently as the 1950s.

title: Scorching Temperatures Bake Middle East Amid Eid al-Adha Celebrations
first_paragraph: A sweltering 125 degrees Fahrenheit in Baghdad on Tuesday; a record 115 degrees in Damascus on Wednesday. And extreme levels of heat in Israel and Lebanon.

title: How Italy Turned Around Its Coronavirus Calamity
first_paragraph: When the coronavirus erupted in the West, Italy was the nightmarish epicenter, a place to avoid at all costs and a shorthand in the United States and much of Europe for uncontrolled contagion.

title: Zimbabwe Locks Down Capital, Thwarting Planned Protests
first_paragraph: When Robert Mugabe was ousted as president of Zimbabwe in a coup in 2017, many in the country hoped for an end to the repression and mismanagement that had characterized his 37 years in office.

title: Hong Kong Delays Election, Citing Coronavirus. The Opposition Isn’t Buying It.
first_paragraph: The Hong Kong government said on Friday that it would postpone the city’s September legislative election by one year because of the coronavirus pandemic, a decision seen by the pro-democracy opposition as a brazen attempt to thwart its electoral momentum and avoid the defeat of pro-Beijing candidates.

title: Border Clashes With Pakistan Leave 15 Afghan Civilians Dead, Officials Say
first_paragraph: Some of the most intense border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan in recent years left at least 15 civilians dead on the Afghan side on Thursday, officials said.

title: In Indonesia, False Virus Cures Pushed by Those Who Should Know Better
first_paragraph: First, Indonesia’s agriculture minister promoted wearing a necklace containing a eucalyptus potion to cure the coronavirus. Not to be outdone, the governor of Bali, a popular resort island, pushed his own remedy: inhaling the steam from boiled arak, a traditional alcohol made from coconuts.

title: What Can Victorian Schools Teach America About Reopening?
first_paragraph: Every night, we wait for the email. Sometimes it comes in the late afternoon, but many nights it doesn’t hit my inbox until 10 or 11 p.m. Eventually, it arrives, written by a beleaguered school principal letting us know that my son’s high school is still closed.

title: U.K. Has Europe’s Worst Surge in Deaths During Pandemic, Study Says
first_paragraph: England has had the greatest rate of excess deaths of any country in Europe during the coronavirus pandemic, with a surge that lasted longer and spread to more places than those in hard-hit nations like Italy and Spain, according to a government report released on Thursday.

title: Pilgrims, Fewer and Socially Distanced, Arrive in Mecca for Annual Hajj
first_paragraph: In any other year, Muslims undertaking the hajj, the annual pilgrimage to the holy city of Mecca that all Muslims are supposed to perform at least once, would drink from a holy well. They would kiss the sacred black stone embedded in the Kaaba, the holiest shrine in Islam, as they thronged the Grand Mosque. Before they left Mecca, they would collect pebbles to ritually stone the devil, casting them at a series of symbolic pillars.

title: China Uses Quarantines as Cover to Detain Dissidents, Activists Say
first_paragraph: On the day of his release from prison, Wang Quanzhang, one of China’s most prominent human rights lawyers, thought he was finally free.

title: Mysterious Coronavirus Outbreak Catches Vietnam by Surprise
first_paragraph: In a world plagued by pandemic, Vietnam seemed like a miracle. As months went by without a single recorded coronavirus death, or even a confirmed case of local transmission, residents began leaving their face masks at home.

title: For Senegal’s Biggest Holiday, a Shortage of the All-Important Sheep
first_paragraph: The couscous was all ready for the lunchtime crowd in Yassin Dicko’s restaurant near one of the biggest sheep markets in Senegal.

title: Palestinians, Slammed for Suppressing Dissent, Free Protest Organizers
first_paragraph: A court in the West Bank on Tuesday ordered the Palestinian Authority to release on bail 12 activists detained over the past 10 days for trying to stage an anti-corruption demonstration, arrests that had prompted sharp criticism that officials were using the pandemic to crack down on dissent.

title: Cold Comfort: France to Ban Heated Terraces, but Not This Winter
first_paragraph: France will ban heaters used by cafes and restaurants on outdoor terraces as part of a package of measures aimed at reducing carbon emissions and energy consumption, the French ecology minister said on Monday.

title: North Korea Thinks He Brought Covid-19. The South Wanted to Arrest Him.
first_paragraph: Three years ago, out of work​ and hungry, Kim Geum-hyok climbed Mount White Horse near his North Korean hometown, Kaesong, brooding on the meaninglessness of life.

title: Spanish Leader Attacks U.K. Quarantine Order, Calling It an ‘Error’
first_paragraph: Spain’s prime minister said Britain had made “an error” by imposing a quarantine on everyone arriving from his country, a decision that blindsided British holidaymakers and has dealt another serious blow to Spain’s crippled tourism industry.

title: Poland Considers Leaving Treaty on Domestic Violence, Spurring Outcry
first_paragraph: The Polish government, emboldened by a narrow election victory this month and undeterred by criticism from European Union leaders, is considering withdrawing from a treaty aimed at curbing domestic violence and protecting women’s rights, with the country’s minister of justice filing paperwork on Monday to start the process.

title: Of Wine, Hand Sanitizer and Heartbreak
first_paragraph: The tanker-truck pulled up and it was time to let it go. The decision to send the wine to the distillery had been made weeks ago. It still hurt. Soon the wine would be sanitizing hand gel.

title: Boris Johnson’s New Tactic Against the Virus: Urge Britons to Lose Weight
first_paragraph: Britain will crack down on junk food advertising and introduce calorie counts on menus in an effort to tackle obesity and ease the pressure on the country’s National Health Service amid the coronavirus pandemic, the government said on Monday.

title: South Korea Confirms a Defector Swam Back to the North
first_paragraph: The authorities in South Korea confirmed on Monday that a 24-year-old man who had defected from North Korea in 2017 had secretly returned to the North, crossing one of the world’s most heavily fortified borders during a pandemic and possibly bringing the coronavirus with him.

title: For French-Algerian Families, Virus Disrupts Cherished Summer Ritual
first_paragraph: Sitting around a table strewn with steaming cups of mint tea, a dozen women were sharing memories of their summer holidays in their homeland, Algeria.

title: Quarantine Order Blindsides Britons Returning From Spain
first_paragraph: Often criticized for a slow response to the coronavirus, the British government moved quickly this weekend to impose a quarantine on anyone arriving from Spain, after a spike in Covid-19 cases there.

title: North Korea Declares Emergency After Suspected Covid-19 Case
first_paragraph: North Korea said on Sunday that it had locked down a city near its border with South Korea and declared a “maximum” national emergency after finding what its leader, Kim Jong-un, said could be the country’s first case of Covid-19 there.

title: As the World Gets Tougher on China, Japan Tries to Thread a Needle
first_paragraph: Earlier this year, as it became clear that the coronavirus pandemic was not going to pass quickly, the Japanese government delayed plans for what would be the first state visit by a Chinese leader to Tokyo since 2008.

title: Brazil’s Bolsonaro, Leading Virus Skeptic, Says He’s No Longer Infected
first_paragraph: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil said Saturday that he had been cured of the coronavirus, appearing to have suffered only mild symptoms from a scourge he has repeatedly downplayed even as it rippled through the country, killing more than 86,000 people.

title: Vietnam, Lauded in Coronavirus Fight, Has First Local Case in 100 Days
first_paragraph: Vietnam, which had gone 100 days without reporting a case of local transmission of the coronavirus, said on Saturday that a 57-year-old grandfather in the central city of Danang had tested positive. How he got the illness remains a mystery.

title: These Monkeys Were Once Revered. Now They Are Taking Over.
first_paragraph: The customers waiting outside a bank in Lopburi, Thailand, left their jewelry at home and kept other treasures out of sight. But danger lurked anyway.

title: After Early Success, Israel’s Netanyahu Faces Fury for Flubbing Virus Fight
first_paragraph: For three nights this week thousands of young Israelis, provoked by what they see as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s flubbed response to the coronavirus scourge, shook off a long political slumber, blocked the streets outside his official residence and demanded that he quit.

title: 73,400 New Coronavirus Cases in U.S., Nearing Single-Day Record
first_paragraph: The United States on Friday came just short of breaking its single-day record for new coronavirus cases, adding more than 73,400, the second-highest daily total, and signaling that infection rates show no signs of slowing.

title: A Chinese Tycoon Denounced Xi Jinping. Now He Faces Prosecution
first_paragraph: China’s ruling Communist Party has expelled an outspoken and prominent property tycoon who denounced the country’s authoritarian leader, Xi Jinping, paving the way for his criminal prosecution and escalating its efforts to quash dissent among the elite.

title: Spain’s Reopening Stumbles as Virus Cases Rise Among Young People
first_paragraph: After already enjoying a long night of graduation celebrations, a throng of young people poured into the Babylon discothèque at 5 a.m. to continue partying in the southern Spanish city of Córdoba.

title: With Officials’ Backing, Dubious Virus Remedies Surge in Latin America
first_paragraph: In Cochabamba, high in the Bolivian Andes, people line up daily outside pharmacies on the central plaza, eager to buy the scarce elixir they hope will ward off Covid-19: chlorine dioxide, a kind of bleach used to disinfect swimming pools and floors.

title: Defying U.N. Ban, Chinese Ships Pay North Korea to Fish in Its Waters
first_paragraph: When the United Nations imposed its toughest sanctions yet on North Korea in 2017, one of the main targets was squid.

title: U.S. Orders China to Close Houston Consulate, Citing Efforts to Steal Trade Secrets
first_paragraph: The United States has abruptly ordered China to close its consulate in Houston, accusing diplomats of aiding economic espionage and the attempted theft of scientific research as the Trump administration sharply escalates its moves against China.

title: China Uses W.H.O. Inquiry to Tout Coronavirus Response
first_paragraph: Chinese officials are hailing a visit by a team of experts sent to Beijing by the World Health Organization to investigate the source of the coronavirus as evidence that the country is a responsible and transparent global power. But the investigation by the W.H.O. is likely to take many months and could face delays.

title: E.U. Adopts Groundbreaking Stimulus to Fight Coronavirus Recession
first_paragraph: After nearly five days of intense haggling, European Union leaders early on Tuesday stepped up to confront one of the gravest challenges in the bloc’s history, agreeing to a landmark spending package to rescue their economies from the ravages of the pandemic.

title: Three Coronavirus Vaccine Developers Report Promising Initial Results
first_paragraph: The race for a vaccine against the coronavirus intensified on Monday as three competing laboratories released promising results from early trials in humans.

title: For Women in Afghan Security Forces, a Daily Battle
first_paragraph: Motivated, educated and fresh from finishing police academy in Turkey, Second Lt. Zala Zazai had stellar qualifications for the job she took in eastern Afghanistan in June. It all mattered little once she started.

title: New Treatment for Covid-19 Shows Promise, but Scientists Urge Caution
first_paragraph: A British drug company said Monday that an inhaled form of a commonly used medicine could slash the odds of Covid-19 patients becoming severely ill, a sliver of good news in the race to find treatments that was met by scientists with equal measures of caution and cheer.

title: Once a Model City, Hong Kong Grapples With a New Coronavirus Wave
first_paragraph: Hong Kong once seemed like a model for how to control the coronavirus. Schools were open. Restaurants and malls buzzed with crowds. Buses and trains operated as usual, with residents dutifully wearing face masks on board.

title: With Tourists Gone, Bali Workers Return to Farms and Fishing
first_paragraph: Ni Nyoman Ayu Sutaryani, a mother of three, made a steady living for two decades working as a masseuse and yoga instructor at Bali’s luxury hotels and spas. Now at 37 she finds herself back on the farm of her childhood village here, standing precariously at the top of a tall bamboo ladder, picking cloves.

title: Europe Said It Was Pandemic-Ready. Pride Was Its Downfall.
first_paragraph: Prof. Chris Whitty, Britain’s chief medical adviser, stood before an auditorium in a London museum two years ago cataloging deadly epidemics.

title: Brazil Health Workers May Have Spread Coronavirus to Indigenous People
first_paragraph: The telltale symptoms began in late May, about a week after government medical workers made a routine visit to the Kanamari Indigenous community in a remote part of the Amazon: Elderly members of the group were struggling to breathe.

title: China Is Using Uighur Labor to Produce Face Masks
first_paragraph: As the coronavirus pandemic continues to drive demand for personal protective equipment, Chinese companies are rushing to manufacture the gear for domestic and global consumption. A New York Times visual investigation has found that some of those companies are using Uighur labor through a contentious government-sponsored program that experts say often puts people to work against their will.

title: Partyers Clash With German Police
first_paragraph: Violence erupted overnight in Frankfurt between police officers and youths who have been partying in a central city square on weekends, with bars and clubs shuttered to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

title: Southern Europe Opens Its Doors to Tourists. Not Many Are Coming.
first_paragraph: Music blared from a beachfront cafe along the normally bustling southwestern coast of Tenerife, the largest of Spain’s Canary Islands. But several tables sat empty, a month after a Covid-19 lockdown had ended, and the doors to many resorts remained shut.

title: ‘Our Role Is to Reduce Their Grief’
first_paragraph: There are no signs to signal the way to the New Valley of Peace, or, as the Iraqis call it, the “Corona cemetery.” But it’s not hard to find: Just follow the cars. It’s the only place they are headed on the rough desert road.

title: Long Waits for U.K. Hospital Treatment as N.H.S. Fights Coronavirus
first_paragraph: After nine months of waiting for surgery, Ruth Fawcett’s knee muscles wasted away, causing her joint to come loose in its socket and leaving her unable to walk without assistance.

title: The Community That Covid-19 Built
first_paragraph: The wagon on Jennifer Ois’s front porch is a symbol of the coronavirus’s silver lining. It’s red and wooden, with black rubber wheels that once fell off, when Ms. Ois was towing her first child and a frozen turkey home from a store many years ago.

title: In a Rare Public Appearance, the Queen Knights Captain Tom
first_paragraph: When Queen Elizabeth II tapped Sir Tom Moore on both shoulders with a sword at Windsor Castle on Friday, she confirmed the noble status of a 100-year-old man whose achievements during the pandemic had already propelled him into the ranks of Britain’s most exalted citizens.

title: A ‘Significant Return to Normality’ by Christmas, U.K. Prime Minister Says
first_paragraph: Stadiums and concert venues in England may reopen in the fall, but nightclubs will remain closed. All schools will welcome students by September, but wedding receptions will be limited to 30 people. And while pubs and restaurants reopened in England earlier this month, the local authorities will be granted new powers to close them when coronavirus cases flare.

title: Ending an Era, British Airways Retires Fleet of Boeing 747s
first_paragraph: British Airways will retire its entire fleet of Boeing 747 airplanes, the company said on Friday, citing the travel downturn and the aircraft’s high operating costs.

title: E.U. Leaders Meet to Discuss Virus Rescue Plan, With Obstacles Ahead
first_paragraph: European Union leaders gathered on Friday to start hammering out a giant aid package to help their economies recover from the coronavirus calamity. But even before they began, the haggling had exposed fundamental differences between member states that must be finessed in coming days if they are to succeed in saving Europe’s economy.

title: Tunisian Woman Sentenced to Prison Over Joke Alluding to the Quran
first_paragraph: As Tunisia battled the coronavirus pandemic in May, and millions in the North African country found themselves confined to their homes, a lighthearted Facebook post about the virus caught Emna Chargui’s eye and brought a brief moment of laughter in a period of uncertainty.

title: India Coronavirus Cases Surge Past One Million
first_paragraph: India hit a milestone on Friday morning that it had made great sacrifices to avoid: recording more than one million coronavirus infections.

title: W.H.O. Asks for Help Fighting Growing Ebola Outbreak
first_paragraph: The World Health Organization raised the alarm Thursday about a growing Ebola outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo and warned of an imminent shortage of funds to fight the deadly disease.

title: Big Business in Bangladesh: Selling Fake Coronavirus Certificates
first_paragraph: The Bangladeshi authorities have arrested the owner of a hospital who they said had sold migrant workers thousands of certificates showing a negative result on coronavirus tests, when in fact many tests were never performed.

title: It’s Merkel’s Last Rodeo. Will a Pandemic Rescue Deal Seal Her Legacy?
first_paragraph: Finishing her 15th year as chancellor of Germany, Angela Merkel, the European Union’s longest-serving and most respected leader, now has her last, best chance to shape the future of the bloc and her own legacy.

title: For U.K.’s Minority Women, Economic Toll of Lockdown Lingers
first_paragraph: Within 10 days of the British government’s lockdown announcement in late March, one woman lost all nine of her cleaning jobs. Another was laid off from a laundromat after she requested a mask, and a live-in nanny was fired for using public transport on her day off.

title: Myanmar Plan to Breed Protected Species in Captivity Draws Criticism
first_paragraph: Myanmar will soon adopt rules that would permit captive breeding of about 175 threatened species, including tigers, pangolins and Irrawaddy dolphins, despite fears that such ventures could encourage poaching of wild animals and spawn new diseases that jump to humans.

title: Homesick Student Cycles From Scotland to Greece During the Pandemic
first_paragraph: Nearly a month into the coronavirus lockdown, Kleon Papadimitriou, a Greek student in Aberdeen, Scotland, was feeling homesick.

title: After Months of Debate, England Requires Face Masks for Shoppers
first_paragraph: Britons, a people famously averse to seeming ruffled in times of distress, have taken slowly, if at all, to face masks during the coronavirus pandemic. Jim Williams says people in his home city, Newcastle, have even yelled at him and shot him angry looks when he wore one.

title: Coronavirus Outbreak at U.S. Bases in Japan Roils an Uneasy Relationship
first_paragraph: An outbreak of coronavirus cases on United States military bases in Okinawa, Japan, has alarmed the island’s local population, which at times has been at odds with the Americans stationed there and has otherwise been successful in limiting Covid-19.

title: Taliban Stage a Major Attack, as Violence Intensifies in Northern Afghanistan
first_paragraph: The Taliban waged a sustained assault against an Afghan intelligence complex in the city of Aybak on Monday, killing at least 11 people and wounding more than 60 others, part of a bloody wave of violence across the country’s north.

title: Bartering Child’s Dress for Food: Life in Lebanon’s Economic Crisis
first_paragraph: For three decades, Chef Antoine El Hajj has appeared on television five days a week to help cooks across Lebanon improve their grasp of the culinary arts.

title: As India Struggles With Coronavirus, Bollywood’s Biggest Star Tests Positive
first_paragraph: When this country’s biggest film star, Amitabh Bachchan, announced Saturday night that he had contracted the coronavirus, a loud alarm bell rang across India.

title: Outspoken Chinese Professor Is Said to Be Released From Detention
first_paragraph: An outspoken Chinese law professor who has denounced the Communist Party’s harsh policies under Xi Jinping was released from detention on Sunday, a week after the police took him away, two people familiar with the professor said.

title: In Latin America, the Pandemic Threatens Equality Like Never Before
first_paragraph: Sandra Abello grew up poor, left school at 11 and spent her teenage years scrubbing floors as a live-in maid. But by this year, something remarkable had happened.

title: An End to Empty Seats on Canada’s Airlines
first_paragraph: Photos of empty airports have come to symbolize the head-spinning drop in air travel during the pandemic. But the more surprising illustration for me involves a now-crowded space.

title: In Singapore, an Orderly Election and a (Somewhat) Surprising Result
first_paragraph: Face-masked citizens lined up to vote in Singapore on Friday, with plenty of space separating them from each other. Their temperatures had been checked. Before receiving their ballots, they spritzed their hands with sanitizer, and many put on disposable gloves.

title: In Tackling Coronavirus, Scotland Asserts Its Separateness From England
first_paragraph: There was nothing particularly festive about Nicola Sturgeon’s recent visit to the Cold Town House, a newly reopened Edinburgh pub, but maybe that was the point. Sipping coffee and surveying plexiglass dividers, Ms. Sturgeon, the leader of Scotland’s government, warned customers not to expect the jolly, sweaty intimacy of nightlife before the coronavirus pandemic.

title: KFC Birthday Party Costs $18,000 in Covid-19 Fines in Australia
first_paragraph: A large takeout order from a KFC in Australia led the police to more than a dozen people hiding at a house party and more than 26,000 Australian dollars in Covid-19 fines, the authorities said Friday.

title: Russian Governor Is Accused of Multiple Murders as Kremlin Claws Back Powers
first_paragraph: After leaving Russia’s regional leaders to take much of the responsibility and heat for battling the coronavirus pandemic, the Kremlin has sent a blunt message to recently empowered local elites: Don’t even think about challenging the will of President Vladimir V. Putin.

title: In South Africa, Burial Traditions Upended by Coronavirus
first_paragraph: In ordinary times, there would have been no question where Zinzile Mweli would be buried: alongside his ancestors in the village where he was born.

title: Dispatch from a Locked-Down Melbourne
first_paragraph: Melbourne winters are notoriously depressing. The days are short and often gray, the rain is cold and persistent. For those of us who live here, coping mechanisms are important. We sit in front of blazing fireplaces at neighborhood pubs, we take trips to the countryside or plan our annual holidays abroad during these long dark months. We gather for family dinners and make sure our exercise routines are uninterrupted.

title: Bolivia President, Jeanine Añez, Tests Positive for Coronavirus
first_paragraph: President Jeanine Añez said Thursday that she has tested positive for the coronavirus, highlighting how the pandemic is spreading to Latin America’s highest echelons of power.

title: ‘Whac-a-Mole’ Against Virus Sounds Reasonable, Unless You’re the Mole
first_paragraph: Fresh buttercream wastes away in an empty cake shop. Young men slip past the lockdown border to reopened pubs in nearby towns. And neighbors blame neighbors for a new outbreak of the coronavirus that has stalled their return to something resembling normal life.

title: U.S. Hits Another Record for New Coronavirus Cases
first_paragraph: Officials across the United States reported more than 59,880 cases on Thursday, setting a single-day record for the sixth time in 10 days, according to a New York Times database.

title: Used Clothes Ban May Crimp Kenyan Style. It May Also Lift Local Design.
first_paragraph: Catherine Muringo’s wardrobe consists of secondhand outfits shipped from all over the world: colorful blouses and jeans from Canada, floral dresses from the United States, trench coats from Australia and leather handbags from the United Kingdom.

title: Serbia Protests Meet Violent Response in Europe’s 1st Major Virus Unrest
first_paragraph: Thousands of Serbs demonstrated for a second consecutive night on Wednesday in response to President Aleksandar Vucic’s management of the coronavirus crisis and wider concerns over the state of democracy in Serbia.

title: Couples Separated by Europe’s Travel Bans Fight to Be Reunited
first_paragraph: Every morning, Marisa Lobato wakes up and checks the news to see if the travel restrictions have changed.

title: Santiago Manuin, Indigenous Leader in Peru, Dies at 63
first_paragraph: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.

title: Erdogan Talks of Making Hagia Sophia a Mosque Again, to International Dismay
first_paragraph: Since it was built in the sixth century, changing hands from empire to empire, Hagia Sophia has been a Byzantine cathedral, a mosque under the Ottomans and finally a museum, making it one of the world’s most potent symbols of Christian-Muslim rivalry and of Turkey’s more recent devotion to secularism.

title: ‘A Colossal Error’: Mexican Leader Under Fire for Plan to Visit Trump
first_paragraph: The risks could be enormous, but they haven’t swayed President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico.

title: Travel Restrictions on Americans Erode a Sense of Passport Privilege
first_paragraph: Five American travelers who set out for a getaway on Sardinia were turned away last week after their private jet landed on the Mediterranean island. In Canada, two Americans were fined for flouting tougher entry restrictions imposed by their northern neighbor.

title: President Bolsonaro of Brazil Tests Positive for Coronavirus
first_paragraph: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil, who has railed against social distancing measures and repeatedly downplayed the threat of the coronavirus as the epidemic in his country became the second-worst in the world, said Tuesday that he, too, had been infected.

title: A Bird? A Plane? No, It’s a Google Balloon Beaming the Internet
first_paragraph: A fleet of high-altitude balloons started delivering internet service to Kenya on Tuesday, extending online access to tens of thousands of people in the first-ever commercial deployment of the technology.

title: Bolsonaro Takes New Coronavirus Test After Attending Lunch Without Mask
first_paragraph: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil said Monday night that he went to the hospital for a lung scan and would take a new test for the novel coronavirus.

title: Laid Off and Locked Up: Virus Traps Domestic Workers in Arab States
first_paragraph: When the nine African women lost their jobs as domestic workers in Saudi Arabia because of the coronavirus lockdown, the agency that had recruited them stuffed them in a bare room with a few thin mattresses and locked the door.

title: Europe’s Roma Already Faced Discrimination. The Pandemic Made It Worse.
first_paragraph: At a checkpoint on the edge of a Roma neighborhood, a police officer held up his hand, stopping Angel Iliev from leaving.

title: Virus Revives Italy’s Age-Old Shadow Safety Net: The Pawnshop
first_paragraph: The economic repercussions of Italy’s lockdown to contain the coronavirus nearly wiped Anita Paris out. Her son, a car mechanic whom she depended on for financial support, couldn’t work. Her small pension didn’t suffice. The welfare checks she had hoped would pour in from the government didn’t materialize.

title: Croatian Prime Minister’s Gamble on Early Elections Pays Off.
first_paragraph: Croatia’s ruling party finished first in a general election on Sunday despite ongoing criticism over the country’s recent handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Iran Admits Serious Damage to Natanz Nuclear Site, Setting Back Program
first_paragraph: A fire at Iran’s main nuclear fuel enrichment site caused significant damage, setting back the country’s nuclear program by months, the government acknowledged on Sunday, after initially saying the destruction was minor.

title: To Buy a Drink in This Border Town, Make Sure You’re in England
first_paragraph: In normal times, no one takes much notice of the invisible border between England and Wales that runs through Llanymynech, a village with a post office, a church and no fewer than three pubs.

title: Italy’s Outdoor Summer Movies See Threat From Ailing Film Industry
first_paragraph: Since the dawn of cinema, Italy’s torrid summers have made outdoor movie showings under the stars a favorite entertainment choice of the season.

title: Tokyo’s First Female Governor Sails to Re-Election Even as Virus Cases Rise
first_paragraph: In rewarding Tokyo’s first female governor, Yuriko Koike, with a second term on Sunday, voters endorsed her highly visible leadership as the sprawling metropolis has avoided the kind of spiraling death toll from the coronavirus seen in other world capitals.

title: In North Korea, Coronavirus Hurts More Than Any Sanctions Could
first_paragraph: On New Year’s Day, North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, called for a “frontal breakthrough to foil the enemies’ sanctions.” The strategy meant finding new sources of income, legal or illegal, and mainly from China.

title: How’s Your Quarantine? If No One’s Banging Gongs, Count Your Blessings
first_paragraph: Spending two weeks quarantined in a hotel room is not a pleasant experience, as thousands of people who’ve flown internationally since the pandemic began can attest.

title: Saroj Khan, Choreographer Who Made Bollywood Sparkle, Dies at 71
first_paragraph: Saroj Khan, a Bollywood choreographer whose film career spanned more than 60 years, and who created some of the industry’s most famous dance scenes in the 1980s and ’90s, died on Friday morning in Mumbai. She was 71.

title: England Drops Its Quarantine for Most Visitors, but Not Those From the U.S.
