first_paragraph: England will drop its mandatory 14-day quarantine for visitors from more than 50 countries but leave the restrictions in place for travelers coming from the United States, deepening the isolation of America and delivering another rebuke to President Trump for his handling of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Days After a Wedding, a Dead Groom and Dozens of Coronavirus Cases
first_paragraph: The groom felt ill at the wedding. Days later, he was dead, and soon more than 100 guests had tested positive for the coronavirus.

title: Australia Thought the Virus Was Under Control. It Found a Vulnerable Spot.
first_paragraph: Ring Mayar spends all day knocking on doors in the western suburbs of Melbourne, asking residents if they have a cough, a fever or chills.

title: Who Will Recover Faster From the Virus? Europe or the U.S.?
first_paragraph: After the devastating financial crisis of 2008 and 2009, the United States recovered much more quickly than Europe, which suffered a double-dip recession. This time, many economists say that Europe may have the edge.

title: At Syrian Aid Summit, a Struggle to Raise Enough to End ‘Downward Spiral’
first_paragraph: As ​the long Syrian war drags into its 10th year, conditions for Syrian civilians ​are ​deteriorating​ quickly, with rapid inflation and the coronavirus pandemic adding to their​ travails​. ​On Tuesday, donors met virtually in Brussels at a conference hosted by the European Union and United Nations to try to find the money to keep the poorest Syrians alive.

title: E.U. Formalizes Reopening, Barring Travelers From U.S.
first_paragraph: The European Union will open its borders to visitors from 15 countries as of Wednesday, but not to travelers from the United States, Brazil or Russia, putting into effect a complex policy that has sought to balance health concerns with politics, diplomacy and the desperate need for tourism revenue.

title: A Surprising Role Model Emerges for Boris Johnson: F.D.R.
first_paragraph: Boris Johnson and Joseph R. Biden Jr. are hardly political bedfellows. But the British prime minister and the American presidential candidate have one thing in common: both have latched on to Franklin D. Roosevelt as a model for how to lead in an era of economic collapse and social upheaval.

title: Putin Pushes Through Referendum Even as Virus Surges in Russia
first_paragraph: Despairing of finding enough beds for patients stricken with the coronavirus, a nurse in the Siberian city of Irkutsk has been forced to begin taking people to a village hospital more than 100 miles away.

title: Coronavirus Is Battering Africa’s Growing Middle Class
first_paragraph: James Gichina started out 15 years ago as a driver shuttling travelers from the airport, worked his way up to safari guide, and with the help of some bank loans, bought two minivans of his own to ferry vacationers around.

title: With Flights Banned, Son Sails Solo Across Atlantic to Reach Father, 90
first_paragraph: Days after Argentina canceled all international passenger flights to shield the country from the new coronavirus, Juan Manuel Ballestero began his journey home the only way possible: He stepped aboard his small sailboat for what turned out to be an 85-day odyssey across the Atlantic.

title: Taiwan Celebrates Pride With a Public Parade
first_paragraph: With the coronavirus pandemic making large gatherings impossible in many places, the biggest Pride events around the globe were mostly forced to scale back or move online.

title: Voters in Poland Appear to Force a Runoff for President
first_paragraph: Poland’s president, Andrzej Duda, fell short of securing a majority of the vote Sunday in Europe’s first socially distanced election, exit polls showed, forcing a runoff vote in two weeks against the second-place finisher, Mayor Rafal Trzaskowski of Warsaw.

title: African Migrants in Yemen Scapegoated for Coronavirus Outbreak
first_paragraph: The Yemeni militiamen rumbled up to the settlement of Al Ghar in the morning, firing their machine guns at the Ethiopian migrants caught in the middle of somebody else’s war. They shouted at the migrants: Take your coronavirus and leave the country, or face death.

title: Poland’s Virus-Delayed Presidential Election Suddenly Looks Tight
first_paragraph: Poland’s governing party swept to power five years ago by appealing to a sense of aggrieved nationalism, and moved quickly to transform the state in ways that critics contend has torn at the fragile fabric of its democracy.

title: How the World Missed Covid-19’s Silent Spread
first_paragraph: Dr. Camilla Rothe was about to leave for dinner when the government laboratory called with the surprising test result. Positive. It was Jan. 27. She had just discovered Germany’s first case of the new coronavirus.

title: E.U. Plans to Bar Most U.S. Travelers When Bloc Reopens
first_paragraph: The European Union is ready to bar most travelers from the United States, Russia, and dozens of other countries considered too risky because they have not controlled the coronavirus outbreak, E.U. officials said Friday.

title: Canada Reopens, but Little Returns to the Old Ways
first_paragraph: At first it was just another of the petty annoyances that come with owning a car. While I was driving along a back road in southern Ontario, the rubber belt on the car’s engine that drives the generator and water pump snapped, setting off alarm chimes and a stern dashboard display warning to pull over.

title: For Boris Johnson’s Science Advisers, Pressure, Anxieties and ‘Pastoral Support’
first_paragraph: When 50 British scientists and government officials got on a Zoom call on May 7, emotions were running high, and not just because Britain had overtaken Italy for having the highest death toll from the coronavirus in Europe.

title: Lockdown? What Lockdown? Heat Wave Brings Britons Out in Droves
first_paragraph: They descended by the tens of thousands on Britain’s southern beaches and jammed into city parks. They cavorted by the hundreds in streams. They attacked police officers who tried to disperse illegal block parties. And hundreds became stuck in mud flats while trying to reach the sea at low tide.

title: Flare-Up in Virus Cases Sets Back Germany’s Efforts to Reopen
first_paragraph: A spike of more than 1,500 coronavirus infections within days has dealt a sudden blow to Germany’s efforts to reopen the country, calling into question the durability of what had been widely considered a success story in managing the contagion in Europe.

title: Israel Announces Partnership With U.A.E., Which Throws Cold Water On It
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel announced a new partnership with the United Arab Emirates on Thursday to cooperate in the fight against the coronavirus, portraying it as the latest advance in the Jewish state’s efforts to build stronger ties with Arab states.

title: 22 Police Officers Injured in Scuffles at Illegal London Block Party
first_paragraph: At least 22 police officers were injured in South London on Wednesday night as they tried to disperse crowds that had gathered for an illegal outdoor party in defiance of coronavirus restrictions, the police said.

title: As New Coronavirus Cases Hit Another Record in the U.S., Some States Delay Reopenings
first_paragraph: The United States on Thursday reported more than 41,000 new coronavirus cases, a record total for the second straight day, as a nationwide sense of urgency grew and caseloads soared in Southern and Western states that were far removed from the worst early outbreaks.

title: For Those Getting Married, a Searchable Domestic Violence Database
first_paragraph: A city in eastern China is preparing to roll out a database that would allow people getting married to check if their prospective partner has a history of domestic violence, in what’s being called the first of its kind in the country.

title: Pilots Discussed Coronavirus, Ignoring Alerts Before Pakistan Crash, Officials Say
first_paragraph: The pilots of a Pakistani airliner that crashed last month in Karachi were busy talking about the coronavirus and repeatedly ignored directions from air traffic controllers before their plane went down, killing 98 people, Pakistan’s aviation minister said Wednesday.

title: For North Korea, Blowing Hot and Cold Is Part of the Strategy
first_paragraph: One of North Korea’s favorite geopolitical strategies has long been compared to dipping alternately in pools of scathingly hot and icy cold water in a public bathhouse.

title: Hit Hard by Coronavirus, Russia Holds a Mostly Mask-Free Victory Parade
first_paragraph: Putting to one side Russia’s unfinished battle against the coronavirus, President Vladimir V. Putin on Wednesday celebrated his country’s victory 75 years ago against Nazi Germany, presiding over an enormous military parade through Red Square that featured thousands of soldiers marching shoulder-to-shoulder without face masks.

title: Judge Scolds Brazil’s President for Violating Mask Law
first_paragraph: A federal judge in Brazil admonished President Jair Bolsonaro for failing to wear a mask in public spaces in the capital, a rare rebuke for a leader who has repeatedly dismissed the danger posed by the coronavirus even as his country became a major hot spot.

title: The Hajj Pilgrimage Is Canceled, and Grief Rocks the Muslim World
first_paragraph: For much of his life, Abdul-Halim al-Akoum stashed away cash in hopes of one day traveling from his Lebanese mountain village to perform the hajj, the pilgrimage to Mecca that all Muslims who can are obliged to make once in their lives.

title: E.U. May Bar American Travelers as It Reopens Borders, Citing Failures on Virus
first_paragraph: European Union countries rushing to revive their economies and reopen their borders after months of coronavirus restrictions are prepared to block Americans from entering because the United States has failed to control the scourge, according to draft lists of acceptable travelers reviewed by The New York Times.

title: Virus Gains Steam Across Latin America
first_paragraph: By late March, the Mexican government calmly predicted that its coronavirus outbreak would peak in April.

title: Singapore Calls for Elections Despite Pandemic
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong of Singapore announced on Tuesday that the city-state would hold the first elections in Southeast Asia since the coronavirus pandemic began.

title: In Fight to Ban Dog Meat, China’s Activists Find an Ally: The Coronavirus
first_paragraph: For years, animal rights activists in China have lobbied policymakers, organized education drives and staged protests to persuade the government and the public to support banning the eating of dogs and cats. They scored few concrete wins.

title: Saudi Arabia Drastically Limits Hajj Pilgrimage to Prevent Viral Spread
first_paragraph: Every year, Saudi Arabia welcomes millions of Muslims from around the world for the hajj pilgrimage, a sacred rite that pumps cash into the economy and enhances the prestige of the monarch.

title: Betraying Frustration with China, E.U. Leaders Press for Progress on Trade Talks
first_paragraph: The European Union pleaded with Chinese leaders at a summit meeting Monday to put more effort into lagging negotiations on an investment and trade deal, an issue that has increasingly vexed the 27-member bloc. But the plea seemed likely to go unanswered by China, which has tightened control over its domestic economy and turned more combative in relations with Western powers.

title: University of Michigan to Drop Out as Presidential Debate Host
first_paragraph: The University of Michigan will withdraw from hosting a presidential debate in October, two people familiar with the school’s plans said Monday night.

title: Under Coronavirus Lockdown, a Philippine Priest Hits the Streets
first_paragraph: When the Rev. Eduardo Vasquez dresses for work these days, his vestments are as protective as they are holy. His cassock has been replaced by a safety suit, his collar hidden behind an N-95 respirator mask. All that identifies him as a priest is his stole, a scarf about two meters long, the perfect length to measure an acceptable social distance.

title: Brazilian Ex-Minister Makes Quick Exit to U.S. as Inquiries Rattle Government
first_paragraph: It was the apex of one of the most tumultuous weeks of Jair Bolsonaro’s presidency. A flurry of arrests and judicial orders targeting supporters of the Brazilian leader plunged the capital into crisis as the country's coronavirus caseload surpassed one million.

title: 8 Hospitals in 15 Hours: A Pregnant Woman’s Crisis in the Pandemic
first_paragraph: Neelam Kumari Gautam woke up at 5 a.m. with shooting labor pains. Her husband put her gently in the back of a rickshaw and motored with her to a hospital. Then another. Then another. Her pain was so intense she could barely breathe, but none would take her.

title: Bullfighting, Already Ailing in Spain, Is Battered by Lockdown
first_paragraph: Extremeño, an imposing black bull who weighs more than half a ton, was set to fight to death next month in the neoclassical ring of the Spanish city of Valencia.

title: Stabbing at U.K. Park Is Declared a ‘Terrorist Incident’
first_paragraph: A stabbing attack at a park in southern England that left three people dead on Saturday is being investigated as a “terrorist incident,” police officials said Sunday.

title: Latin America’s Virus Villains: Corrupt Officials Collude With Price Gougers for Body Bags and Flimsy Masks
first_paragraph: Of all the schemes that have siphoned resources from Latin American countries fighting the coronavirus, the body bag conspiracy might be the most brazen.

title: Russians Eat Burgers in Gloves. Should Everyone?
first_paragraph: When you enter a home in Moscow, you take off your shoes. When you go to a play, you have to check your coat. When you eat a burger, you often wear gloves.

title: When It’s Illegal to Travel in Your Own Country
first_paragraph: Hi, this is Catherine Porter, a Canada correspondent for The Times, based in Toronto. I am taking over the Canada Letter this week from Ian Austen, who is on vacation.

title: Pandemic Gives S.O.S. a New Meaning for U.K. Cheesemakers: Save Our Stilton
first_paragraph: First the phones fell silent, then the email inbox abruptly emptied of orders. At Hartington Creamery, one of just six companies that produce Britain’s famous blue Stilton cheese, things looked ominous from the moment the coronavirus lockdown began and pubs and restaurants closed.

title: A Royal Ascot Without the Crowds, but Hats and Frocks on Full Display
first_paragraph: For years, the Royal Ascot horse races have marked a high point on Maria Zherebtsova’s calendar, not just as a socialite but as a much-sought-after milliner whose creations have bedecked many a high-class cranium.

title: In This Coronavirus Wave, China Tries Something New: Restraint
first_paragraph: At an apartment complex in southern Beijing that is under lockdown, residents could not leave their homes in a gated cluster of low-rise brick buildings. Uniformed security guards and medical workers in protective gear watched the gate.

title: U.S. Troops in Afghanistan Reduced to 8,600, General Says
first_paragraph: The United States has reduced the number of troops it has in Afghanistan to 8,600 in accordance with a preliminary peace deal with the Taliban, a top American general said on Thursday, even as other aspects of the plan to end the war have faced setbacks and delays.

title: Returning to a Sense of Normalcy — or Not?
first_paragraph: Earlier this month, I found myself standing among thousands of people at a Black Lives Matter protest in Melbourne where I was reporting, wondering if I was too close to them.

title: Will India Side With the West Against China? A Test Is at Hand
first_paragraph: For years, the United States and its allies have tried to persuade India to become a closer military and economic partner in confronting China’s ambitions, painting it as a chance for the world’s largest democracy to counterbalance the largest autocracy.

title: China Indicts 2 Canadians on Spying Charges, Escalating Dispute
first_paragraph: Chinese officials said on Friday they had indicted two Canadians on charges of espionage, escalating Beijing’s punitive campaign against Canada over the arrest of a top executive of the Chinese technology giant Huawei.

title: Coronavirus in Brazil: What You Need to Know
first_paragraph: Latin America became an epicenter of the coronavirus pandemic in May, driven by Brazil’s ballooning caseload. Ten months after its first known case, Brazil has had more than 7.9 million cases and over 200,000 deaths.

title: Portugal Honors a Diplomat Who Saved Jews From the Nazis
first_paragraph: Eighty years after he helped save thousands of Jews from Nazi persecution by defying the orders of his own Portuguese government, a diplomat who provided them with visas to leave Nazi-occupied France will be honored in the national Pantheon in Lisbon.

title: Anger Surges in India Over Deadly Border Brawl With China
first_paragraph: An Indian government minister has called for Chinese restaurants to be closed. Other Indian officials have suddenly put contracts to Chinese companies under review. And crowds of men are now smashing Chinese-made televisions in the street.

title: Coronavirus Fears in China Find a New Target: Salmon
first_paragraph: When a new coronavirus outbreak emerged last week in Beijing, residents were jolted by reports that traces of the virus had been found on a cutting board used for imported salmon, and the backlash was swift.

title: England’s ‘World Beating’ System to Track the Virus Is Anything But
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain unveiled last month a “world beating” operation to track down people who had been exposed to the coronavirus, giving the country a chance to climb out of lockdown without losing sight of where infections were spreading.

title: For Boris Johnson, a Rare Respite From Bad News
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson has always been a riverboat gambler, and as Britain emerges, blinking into the light, from a three-month lockdown, he is making one of the biggest bets of his career: that he can safely reopen a country that has been hit harder by the pandemic than any in Europe.

title: Beijing’s Partial Lockdown a Sign of the World’s New Normal
first_paragraph: The Chinese economy had been firing back up. Travelers had been returning to fill trains and planes. Communist Party leaders had been celebrating their success in defeating the coronavirus.

title: Britain’s Contact Tracing for Coronavirus Falls Short of Promises
first_paragraph: When Britain unveiled an ambitious new contact-tracing system to help pinpoint clusters of infections as they emerge, Prime Minister Boris Johnson described it as a “world beating” operation.

title: President of Honduras Hospitalized for Coronavirus
first_paragraph: The president of Honduras was hospitalized on Wednesday for Covid-19 and is being treated for pneumonia, a day after testing positive for the illness, a government health official said.

title: Schools Shut in Beijing as Coronavirus Flares
first_paragraph: Beijing raised its level of health alert to the second highest on Tuesday, ordering schools to close and urging people to work from home as China’s government pressed to extinguish a spike in coronavirus infections menacing the capital.

title: Europe Rolls Out Contact Tracing Apps, With Hope and Trepidation
first_paragraph: When three people in the northern Italian region of Liguria tested positive for the coronavirus last week, they gave their doctors permission to punch into a national server anonymous codes generated by a new contact tracing app on their phones. Moments later, the phones of people who had also voluntarily downloaded the app and had come into contact with them buzzed with an alert.

title: Common Drug Reduces Coronavirus Deaths, Scientists Report
first_paragraph: In an unexpected sign of hope amid the expanding pandemic, scientists at the University of Oxford said on Tuesday that an inexpensive and commonly available drug reduced deaths in patients with severe Covid-19, the illness caused by the coronavirus.

title: Hungary Moves to End Rule by Decree, but Orban’s Powers May Stay
first_paragraph: Long before Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary was granted the power to rule by decree to combat the outbreak of the coronavirus, his control over the ruling party and the state itself was pretty much complete.

title: In Europe, Travel Returns, but Not Confidence About What Comes Next
first_paragraph: Europe’s internal borders, closed three months ago in a frenzy of panicked uncertainty, are opening again. The uncertainty remains even if the sense of panic has eased.

title: Coronavirus Breaches Chinese Capital, Rattling Officials
first_paragraph: The authorities in Beijing placed a swath of the city under lockdown on Monday and tested tens of thousands of people as they rushed to contain a new coronavirus outbreak that marked an unnerving breach in China’s capital.

title: Pakistan’s Lockdown Ended a Month Ago. Now Hospital Signs Read ‘Full.’
first_paragraph: Pakistanis stricken by the coronavirus are being turned away from hospitals that have simply closed their gates and put up signs reading “full house.” Doctors and nurses are falling ill at alarming rates, and are also coming under physical assault from desperate and angry families.

title: For Migrants in Russia, Virus Means No Money to Live and No Way to Leave
first_paragraph: Migrant workers from Central Asia, shrugging off the risk of coronavirus infection, have gathered in groups each day outside their countries’ embassies in Moscow, banging on doors and fences and shouting for officials to come out and tell them when they can finally get on a charter flight home.

title: Putin Says U.S. Is in ‘Deep Internal Crisis’
first_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Sunday described the United States as a country gripped by a “deep internal crisis” and attributed it to what he said was a refusal by opponents of President Trump to accept his “obvious” 2016 election victory and his legitimacy as leader.

title: Desperate for Any Coronavirus Care, Afghans Flock to Herbalist’s ‘Vaccine’
first_paragraph: Every day, thousands of people swarmed Hakeem Alokozai’s herbal clinic in Kabul seeking their three drops of his Covid-19 “vaccine.” Some carried IV drips, others oxygen cylinders. Some were brought in ambulances, others in the back of Toyota station wagons. They were laborers, officers of the security forces and even lawmakers in the country’s Parliament.

title: Coronavirus Created an Obstacle Course for Safe Abortions
first_paragraph: When a 19-year-old woman from southern Poland decided to end her pregnancy at 18 weeks, she knew the only way to get an abortion was to rush to a neighboring European country.

title: A Stimulus Backlash Delivers a Global Warning: Value Female Workers
first_paragraph: Shelley Duggan became an essential worker when Australia declared that her job at a suburban child care center must be preserved so that doctors and nurses would have a place to send their children during the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Beijing Shuts Down Seafood Market After Dozens Test Positive for Coronavirus
first_paragraph: The Beijing authorities shut down a major seafood and produce market and locked down several residential complexes on Saturday after 53 people tested positive for the coronavirus in the city, renewing fears that China’s grip on the pandemic is not yet secure.

title: Too Close for Comfort, and the Virus, in Russia’s Communal Apartments
first_paragraph: Through the thin wall separating her from her neighbors, Dr. Anzhela Kirilova began to hear the rasping cough associated with Covid-19 sometime in May. That was hardly a surprise, as a few weeks earlier her neighbors had heard the same cough coming from her room.

title: Prime Minister Boris Johnson Stirs Culture War Over Churchill Statue
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain on Friday stirred a fraught debate over symbols of his country’s past, accusing protesters of seeking to “censor our past” and telling them it was “absurd and shameful” that a statue of Winston Churchill needed to be covered to protect it from being vandalized.

title: How Much Longer Will the Border Stay Shut?
first_paragraph: This week Prime Minister Justin Trudeau may have resolved some of the concerns Canada Letter readers have raised in emails about the border closing with the United States. A tweak to its rules now means that married and common law couples who had found themselves unable to reunite if they weren’t both Canadian citizens can now do so.

title: Putin Wants Parades Ahead of Key Vote. Local Officials Aren’t So Sure.
first_paragraph: When President Vladimir V. Putin ordered Russia’s annual military parade to be rescheduled for later this month, he cast it as a sign of life returning to normal in his virus-stricken nation.

title: French Police Push Back Against Proposed Reforms
first_paragraph: The French police, furious at a popular backlash against them in the wake of the George Floyd killing, have pushed back against government attempts to change their practices and discipline officers suspected of racism, demonstrating Friday in Paris and throwing down handcuffs in front of police stations all over France.

title: Amid a Pandemic, ‘Batman’ Matters More Than Ever
first_paragraph: The bat is considered lucky in China; the words for bat and good fortune sound alike in Chinese. But Wang Linfa didn’t give much thought to the order Chiroptera while growing up in Shanghai in the 1960s and ’70s, when the main sign of nighttime life was the soft whir of commuters bicycling home from factories.

title: Risking Their Lives in Canada’s Pandemic and Hoping That’s Enough to Stay
first_paragraph: Sterly Lucien, a Haitian orderly in a Quebec nursing home, has had sleepless nights for two years, fearful that she and her young son could be deported at anytime. But the 30-year old may find reprieve from an unlikely source: the deadly coronavirus.

title: As Floating Propaganda Irks North Korea, the South Isn’t Happy Either
first_paragraph: The hydrogen balloons float over the world’s most heavily guarded border, unleashing their payloads in North Korea like snowflakes: propaganda leaflets calling Kim Jong-un, the North’s leader, a “devil” who will meet the same bloody end as Saddam Hussein of Iraq and Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya.

title: Europe Resurfaces to Find Odd Mix of the Familiar and the Alien
first_paragraph: Europe is emerging from a monthslong lockdown. But the universe in which Europeans are resurfacing is neither the reality they knew, nor an entirely new one.

title: As Prime Minister, Boris Johnson Struggles to Find His Voice
first_paragraph: After a week when protesters battled with police outside his residence, spray-painted “racist” on a memorial to Winston Churchill and dumped the statue of a 17th-century slave trader into Bristol harbor, Prime Minister Boris Johnson knew he was going to face questions about race and justice in Parliament.

title: ISIS Attacks Surge in Iraq Amid Debate on U.S. Troop Levels
first_paragraph: The assailants came at dusk, creeping on foot through the dusty palm groves near the Tigris River, armed only with a rocket-propelled grenade, a light machine gun and Kalashnikovs. They had laid roadside bombs to kill anyone who rushed to help the unsuspecting local guards, who were in their sights.

title: I.M.F. Approves Critical Loan for Ukraine
first_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has won an important vote of confidence in his promised anti-corruption efforts as the International Monetary Fund has approved a multibillion-dollar lending program for the country.

title: Ukraine’s Backlog of Babies Born to Surrogates Begins to Ease
first_paragraph: For weeks, more than 100 foreign genetic parents of babies born to surrogate mothers in Ukraine have been waiting nervously, prevented by Ukraine’s rigid coronavirus restrictions from entering the country to pick up their newborns.

title: Indonesia’s New Coronavirus Concern: A Post-Pandemic Baby Boom
first_paragraph: The government vehicles began appearing in Indonesian towns and cities in May, equipped with loudspeakers blaring a blunt message.

title: In a Province No Stranger to War, Preparing to Battle a New Enemy
first_paragraph: An activist who has supported the democracy protests against Syria’s authoritarian president since they began nine years ago knows a thing or two about battling adversity. But Hosam al-Ali, 35, is more than a little worried about his new adversary: the coronavirus.

title: The World Reopens, Despite Skyrocketing Coronavirus Cases
first_paragraph: Two months ago, when there were roughly one million confirmed coronavirus cases and the primal politics of survival was sweeping the world, shutting down was the order of the day.

title: Its Defenses Undone by a Virus, France Seeks Lessons From a Lost War
first_paragraph: It became the indispensable book of the pandemic, its French author revealing how society’s weaknesses and human frailties gave way to disaster. As the coronavirus tore through France, intellectuals, historians and journalists cracked open their old copies in search of eternal truths in an unsettling time.

title: ‘Get Rid of Them’: A Statue Falls as Britain Confronts Its Racist History
first_paragraph: With a mix of pent-up fury and sudden elation, the protesters who toppled a bronze statue of the 17th-century slave trader Edward Colston in Bristol, England, on Sunday recalled the angry crowds that brought down statues of Saddam Hussein, Stalin and even King George III.

title: Just as Air Travel Is Picking Up, U.K. Imposes a Quarantine
first_paragraph: When the coronavirus was spreading at breakneck speed this spring, Britain’s government flatly refused to quarantine travelers, even those arriving from virus hot spots like Spain or Iran.

title: Mexico’s Leftist Leader Rejects Big Spending to Ease Virus’s Sting
first_paragraph: For the second time in a month, top business leaders sat down with Mexico’s president to implore him to do more to save the economy.

title: China Hails Its Virus Triumphs, and Glosses Over Its Mistakes
first_paragraph: Under continued fire for its early mishandling of the coronavirus, the Chinese government vigorously defended its actions in a new, detailed account on Sunday that portrays the country’s approach to combating the outbreak as a model for the world.

title: China Vowed to Keep Wildlife Off the Menu, a Tough Promise to Keep
first_paragraph: Bamboo rats lifted Mao Zuqin out of poverty. Now, because of the coronavirus pandemic, poverty threatens again.

title: U.K. Lab to Sidestep Drug Industry to Sell Potential Virus Vaccine
first_paragraph: A prominent British laboratory is forming a special partnership that would sidestep the drug industry to sell a potential vaccine against the coronavirus without profits or licensing fees in Britain and in low- and middle-income countries.

title: China Defends Its Coronavirus Response
first_paragraph: The Chinese government on Sunday strongly defended its handling of the coronavirus, pushing back at criticism that officials had suppressed early reports of the outbreak and contending instead that China had set a strong example for how to combat it.

title: Coronavirus Depletes the Keepers of Europe’s Memory
first_paragraph: For years, Gildo Negri visited schools to share his stories about blowing up bridges and cutting electrical wires to sabotage Nazis and fascists during World War II. In January, the 89-year-old made another visit, leaving his nursing home outside Milan to help students plant trees in honor of Italians deported to concentration camps.

title: Amazon Deforestation Soars as Pandemic Hobbles Enforcement
first_paragraph: Since coming to office, President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil has enabled increased razing of the Amazon rainforest.

title: Huge Crowds Around the Globe March in Solidarity Against Police Brutality
first_paragraph: They were warned by Prime Minister Scott Morrison of Australia against attending Black Lives Matter marches on Saturday because of the coronavirus risk, but tens of thousands would not be deterred.

title: Coronavirus Nearly Ended Street Homelessness in U.K. Maybe Not for Long.
first_paragraph: Driving through the East London borough of Newham recently, Ryan Anderson and Billy Tattingham pointed out some of the places they had slept before the coronavirus outbreak.

title: Macron Beat Back the Coronavirus. France Is Not Impressed.
first_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron’s government has beaten back the coronavirus, prevented mass layoffs, propped up the salaries of the unemployed, staved off long food lines, and achieved a lower death rate than its neighbors, Germany excepted.

title: How the Coronavirus Makes a No-Deal Brexit More Likely
first_paragraph: The coronavirus epidemic in Britain has killed more than 40,000 people, sickened hundreds of thousands more, including Prime Minister Boris Johnson, and paralyzed the economy. Now it may claim another casualty: a trade agreement between Britain and the European Union.

title: Musicians Playing Through the Lockdown, to One Listener at a Time
first_paragraph: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving more than 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns. Read all their dispatches.

title: Mexico Is Reopening After Quarantine. Many Worry It’s Too Early.
first_paragraph: Packed street markets. Buzzing metro stations. Thronged sidewalks. And noticeably fewer people wearing masks.

title: Coronavirus Rips Into Regions Previously Spared
first_paragraph: For months, one enduring mystery of the coronavirus was why some of the world’s most populous countries, with rickety health systems and crowded slums, had managed to avoid the brunt of an outbreak that was burning through relatively affluent societies in Europe and the United States.

title: Amsterdam’s Red Light Zone Stays Shut as Rest of City Edges Open
first_paragraph: The red lights still shone above the windows in De Wallen, Amsterdam’s main red-light district, but the windows themselves were empty.

title: What Will It Take to Reopen the World to Travel?
first_paragraph: After months of locked-down borders, countries that have stifled the coronavirus are trying to choreograph a risky dance: how to bring back visitors without importing another burst of uncontrolled contagion.

title: Powerful Cyclone Lashes Mumbai as City Grapples With Coronavirus
first_paragraph: A powerful cyclone slammed into India’s coast Wednesday afternoon, striking the commercial hub of Mumbai, lashing beach towns with heavy rain and strong winds, and pushing thousands of people into emergency shelters.

title: Yemen Aid Falls Short, Threatening Food and Health Programs
first_paragraph: International donors pledged about $1.35 billion in humanitarian aid for Yemen on Tuesday, far short of the $2.4 billion the United Nations had said was needed to pull a country shredded by years of war, hunger and disease from the brink of further disaster.

title: Embattled at Home, Trump Finds Himself Isolated Abroad, Too
first_paragraph: With American cities burning and the coronavirus still raging, killing more people than in any other country, President Trump also has growing problems overseas. He has never before been so isolated and ignored, even mocked.

title: As Protests Engulf the United States, China Revels in the Unrest
first_paragraph: The cartoon shows the Statue of Liberty cracking into pieces, a police officer breaking through its copper robe. A man’s head lies on the ground in front of the White House, its facade splattered with blood.

title: New Ebola Outbreak in Congo, Already Hit by Measles and Coronavirus
first_paragraph: A fresh outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus has flared up in the Democratic Republic of Congo, a country that was already contending with the world’s largest measles epidemic, as well as the coronavirus.

title: Putin Sets New Date for Vote on Extending His Rule
first_paragraph: Pushing to get his political program back on track, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said on Monday that a referendum on constitutional changes that would allow him to dispense with term limits and stay in office until 2036 would be held on July 1.

title: Global Anger Grows Over George Floyd Death, and Becomes an Anti-Trump Cudgel
first_paragraph: Mass protests over the police killing of another black man in the United States spread globally in the past few days, as many demonstrators not only expressed solidarity with their American counterparts but denounced racism in their own countries.

title: Resisting Lockdown, Nicaragua Becomes a Place of Midnight Burials
first_paragraph: Just hours after Yamil Acevedo died in a hospital, funeral home workers in hazardous materials suits strapped his coffin to the back of a pickup truck, drove it to a cemetery and buried him in the dark of night.

title: Coronavirus Turns a Spanish Sea Delicacy Back Into Daily Fare
first_paragraph: With an intensity of flavor to match their color, the big, bright-red prawns caught off Spain’s eastern coast are the kind of delicacy that someone might eat once or twice in a year and remember fondly for the rest of it.

title: U.S. Sends Two Million Doses of Hydroxychloroquine to Brazil
first_paragraph: The United States has delivered two million doses of a malaria drug to Brazil for use in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic, and the two countries are embarking on a joint research effort to study whether the drug is safe and effective for the prevention and early treatment of Covid-19, the White House announced Sunday.

title: China and India Brawl at 14,000 Feet Along the Border
first_paragraph: High in the Himalayas, an enormous fistfight erupted in early May between the soldiers of China and India. Brawls at 14,000 feet along their inhospitable and disputed frontier are not terribly unusual, but what happened next was.

title: In Some Nations, Coronavirus Is Only One of Many Outbreaks
first_paragraph: A dengue epidemic ravaged Honduras last year, sickening over 100,000 people and leaving 180 dead. As this year began, officials braced for another surge in cases of the mosquito-borne disease and wondered how they would manage with their frail public health system and shortage of trained personnel.

title: Coronavirus Slams Broken, Embattled Yemen
first_paragraph: In northern Yemen, more and more people are falling ill and dying after having trouble breathing, yet the Iran-backed group that controls the region, the Houthis, has acknowledged only a few coronavirus deaths.

title: When Going to Work Means Taking a Calculated Risk
first_paragraph: Last week I spoke with one of Canada’s leading experts about the effects of working from home. But the coronavirus shutdown has also created a class of people who still go to their regular workplaces but may not want to be there.

title: In Brazil, a President Under Fire Lashes Out at Investigators
first_paragraph: The embattled president of Brazil stood outside his mansion on Thursday, indignant and angry, wearing a necktie patterned with assault rifles.

title: Older Italians Warily Eye Young Crowds, Fearing 2nd Coronavirus Wave
first_paragraph: After months of living under a strict lockdown in Italy, a closely gathered group of teenagers welcomed a warm evening this week at a verdant park in Milan, gazing at phone screens, embracing and forming a small circle around a playful dog. No one wore a mask.

title: Its Coronavirus Caseload Soaring, India Is Reopening Anyway
first_paragraph: Its coronavirus cases are skyrocketing, putting it among the world’s most worrisome pandemic zones in recent weeks. Nonetheless, India is reopening, lifting its lockdown at what experts fear may be the worst time.

title: ‘It’s Too Late’: In Sprawling Indonesia, Coronavirus Surges
first_paragraph: The 1,340 Maluku Islands are a long way from anywhere. So remote are these Indonesian isles that the country’s most famous novelist was imprisoned there in a gulag that was actually an archipelago.

title: Proud of Your Lockdown Baking? This Man Built a Giant Kookaburra
first_paragraph: Some have taken to baking to while away the hours during coronavirus lockdown; others embraced gardening. For Farvardin Daliri, it was the perfect opportunity to complete his magnum opus: a 15-foot-tall replica of a bird known as a laughing kookaburra.

title: ‘It’s Not the Virus’: Mexico’s Broken Hospitals Become Killers, Too
first_paragraph: The senseless deaths torment doctors and nurses the most: The man who died because an inexperienced nurse unplugged his ventilator. The patient who died from septic shock because no one monitored his vital signs. The people whose breathing tubes clogged after being abandoned in their hospital beds for hours on end.

title: A €750 Billion Virus Recovery Plan Thrusts Europe Into a New Frontier
first_paragraph: For decades, even when the 2008 financial crisis threatened to blow the bloc apart, the European Union’s wealthier nations resisted the notion of collective debt. But the coronavirus has so fundamentally damaged the bloc’s economy that it is now forcing European leaders to consider the sort of unified and sweeping response once thought unworkable.

title: Boris Johnson Defends ‘Toxic’ Aide Again. Why Protect a Political Burden?
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson went to the mat yet again on Wednesday for his embattled adviser, Dominic Cummings, signaling to lawmakers that he had no plans to dismiss Mr. Cummings for breaching the rules by driving 260 miles to his parents’ house during the country’s coronavirus lockdown.

title: ‘Overtaken by Aliens’: India Faces Another Plague as Locusts Swarm
first_paragraph: Magan Doodi, a groundskeeper at a golf course in Jaipur, was making his rounds earlier this week when he saw the sky suddenly turn a weird pink.

title: Canada’s ‘Voice of the Nation’ Rings Out in a Capital Quieted by a Virus
first_paragraph: Finding a spot on the sweeping lawn in front of Canada’s ornately Gothic Parliament buildings to hear a concert this month was not a problem in the middle of a pandemic.

title: Visiting My Grandparents, Separated by Plexiglass
first_paragraph: Elian Peltier, who is based in London, covered the coronavirus pandemic in Spain before returning to his home country, France. We asked him to tell us about a visit to his grandparents.

title: Dominic Cummings Offers a Sorry-Not-Sorry for U.K. Lockdown Breach
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson took a breathtaking gamble with his own popularity on Monday, allowing his closest aide to go public with a detailed, yet stubbornly unapologetic, explanation for making a 260-mile journey that broke lockdown rules and ignited a political firestorm in Britain.

title: ISIS Prisoners Threaten U.S. Mission in Northeastern Syria
first_paragraph: A year after American-backed forces seized the last remnant of territory under Islamic State rule in Syria, some 10,000 captured ISIS fighters in Kurdish-run wartime prisons pose “a significant risk” to the United States mission in the country’s northeast, military commanders say.

title: On a Scottish Isle, Nursing Home Deaths Expose a Covid-19 Scandal
first_paragraph: On the Isle of Skye off the western coast of Scotland, residents thought they had sealed themselves off from the coronavirus. They shuttered hotels. Officials warned of police checks. Traffic emptied on the only bridge from the mainland.

title: Coronavirus Threatens China’s Devotion to Chopsticks and Sharing Food
first_paragraph: At Chilli Kitchen in Beijing, spicy and mouth-numbing Sichuan dishes are laid out family style. Using red chopsticks, diners dive into steaming bowls of pork wontons bathed in fragrant chili oil and sesame seeds, and rummage through platters filled with dried red chili peppers to unearth juicy bits of roasted fish.

title: Putin Speaks, Officials Shrug, and Doctors Are Caught in the Middle
first_paragraph: Assailed by critics as an absentee leader at the start of the coronavirus crisis in Russia, President Vladimir V. Putin re-emerged with a splash on state television last month to show that he cared and was taking charge.

title: Spain’s Courts, Already Strained, Face Crisis as Lockdown Lifts
first_paragraph: A flood of new court cases, some with little precedent, is expected to deluge a Spanish judicial system already gasping for breath, bogged down by delays and lagging in technology.

title: New Zealand Earthquake Interrupts Jacinda Ardern’s TV Interview
first_paragraph: A sizable earthquake struck New Zealand on Monday, shaking Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern during a live television interview, but failing to cause major damage or disrupt Ms. Ardern’s calm demeanor.

title: Boris Johnson Backs Top Aide Accused of Flouting Lockdown Rules
first_paragraph: Prime Minister Boris Johnson, defying a storm of criticism, said on Sunday that he would not dismiss his most influential adviser, Dominic Cummings, for breaching Britain’s lockdown rules by driving across the country to visit relatives, even when he was falling ill with the coronavirus.

title: Push to Reopen Houses of Worship in Europe and Mideast Brings Perils and Tensions
first_paragraph: As nations weigh the calculus of reopening parts of society after locking down because of the coronavirus, Germany has plunged ahead after bringing its outbreak under control, reopening houses of worship and allowing the faithful to gather again in larger numbers.

title: For Some Italians, the Future of Work Looks Like the Past
first_paragraph: On a small farm outside Rome, workers crouched in the corridors of a cornfield and tended to stalks for the coming harvest. The ones from Morocco, Romania and Nigeria knew exactly what to do. It was the new Italian hires who needed help.

title: Hong Kong Police Fire Tear Gas as Protesters Resist China’s Grip
first_paragraph: Thousands of protesters swarmed some of Hong Kong’s busiest neighborhoods on Sunday, singing, chanting and erecting roadblocks of torn-up bricks and debris, as the police repeatedly fired tear gas, pepper spray and a water cannon during the city’s largest street mobilization in months.

title: Afghan Sides Agree to Rare Cease-Fire During Eid al-Fitr
first_paragraph: The Taliban and the Afghan government announced a cease-fire for the three days of the Islamic festival Eid al-Fitr, which starts on Sunday in Afghanistan, offering the war-torn nation a rare respite from violence that has been intensifying.

title: Is It Time to Stop Clapping for Health Care Workers? An Organizer Thinks So
first_paragraph: On Thursday nights, Britons bang pots and pans and let out hearty cheers of support for doctors and nurses who care for coronavirus patients and for other essential workers amid the pandemic.

title: Rattled by a Pandemic, People Turn to Leaders — Any Leaders
first_paragraph: As world leaders grapple with when and how to safely reopen their countries, many are also facing a political problem: how to maintain support as they oversee tanking economies, stifling restrictions and staggering death tolls.

title: European Defense and ‘Strategic Autonomy’ Are Also Coronavirus Victims
first_paragraph: The coronavirus has upended the best-laid plans and priorities of many, including the European Union. But one of the biggest casualties may be European efforts to build a more credible and independent European military.

title: Jacinda Ardern Sold a Drastic Lockdown With Straight Talk and Mom Jokes
first_paragraph: Halfway into a Facebook Live video last week, updating the world on New Zealand’s plan to reopen restaurants, schools and even movie theaters, Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern noticed a concern cropping up among the commenters: They thought she looked tired.

title: Virus Lockdown Forces Iran Into Its First Virtual Quds Day
first_paragraph: For the past four decades, on the last Friday of Ramadan, supporters of Iran’s government have marched to denounce Israel. They burn Israel’s flag. They mock effigies of the leaders of Israel and of its patron, the United States. They chant pledges to liberate Jerusalem, or Quds, as the city is known in Arabic.

title: What’s Lost and Gained When We Put In 9-to-5 From Home?
first_paragraph: On Thursday, Tobi Lütke, the founder and chief executive of Ottawa-based Shopify, announced on Twitter that most of his company’s 5,000 employees had permanently become stay-at-home workers.

title: Argentina Tries to Escape Default as It Misses Bond Payment
first_paragraph: Argentina missed a bond payment on Friday and inched closer to another crushing default, which would plunge it into a new period of economic isolation and deepen a recession that has been exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Britain Orders a 14-Day Quarantine on Arriving Travelers
first_paragraph: Britain on Friday moved ahead with a 14-day mandatory quarantine on arriving travelers, and heavy fines for those who break the rules, outlining strict new travel restrictions as other European nations are thinking about easing theirs.

title: Coronavirus Cases Fall in Europe’s Capitals, but Fears Over Reopening Linger
first_paragraph: During a week of bluebird skies and Mediterranean temperatures, when sunbathers thronged parks and cars poured back onto streets, one sound has been notably absent in London: the wail of ambulance sirens.

title: Why the Call to Prayer Made Me Cry This Ramadan
first_paragraph: Abdi Latif Dahir is a Kenyan who was appointed the East Africa correspondent for The New York Times last year. He has fasted every day of Ramadan since he was 9 years old.

title: Democracy Fades in Malaysia as Old Order Returns to Power
first_paragraph: The members of Malaysia’s Parliament, wearing face masks to match their crisp white uniforms, convened this week in the vast lower house chamber for the first time this year.

title: U.K. to Quarantine All Incoming Air Travelers; a Chinese Coronavirus Vaccine Shows Promise
first_paragraph: Britain will quarantine everyone flying into the country, including citizens, for 14 days beginning June 8 to fight the spread of the coronavirus, Home Secretary Priti Patel announced on Friday.

title: Boris Johnson Avoids Criminal Inquiry Into His Dealings as London’s Mayor
first_paragraph: A British police watchdog agency said on Thursday that it would not conduct a criminal investigation into Prime Minister Boris Johnson over claims that as mayor of London he had done official favors for an American businesswoman whose apartment he sometimes visited during working hours.

title: Cyclone Amphan’s Death Toll Rises to 80 in India and Bangladesh
first_paragraph: More than 80 people were killed by the powerful cyclone that slammed into India and Bangladesh on Wednesday, wiping out thousands of homes and drenching low-lying areas in torrential rain, officials said on Thursday.

title: Coronavirus Changed China’s Big Political Event. Here’s What to Expect.
first_paragraph: China’s biggest event on the political calendar, the annual session of the National People’s Congress, is always a tightly choreographed legislative pageant aimed at conveying the strength of the ruling Communist Party.

title: In Istanbul Under Lockdown, Baklava Makers Are Essential Workers
first_paragraph: Every weekend, for over a month now, Istanbul has been under a strict curfew because of the coronavirus. No one is allowed out, not for exercise or groceries, and the police impose fines. Sometimes, like last weekend and next, the street-emptying lockdown stretches for four days to take in public holidays.

title: After New Coronavirus Outbreaks, China Imposes Wuhan-Style Lockdown
first_paragraph: In Shulan, a city in China’s northeast, the streets are eerily quiet, devoid of taxis and buses. Apartment complexes have been sealed off, confining residents inside. Teams of government workers go door to door rounding up sick people as part of what they call a “wartime” campaign.

title: As Paris Tiptoes Toward Normalcy, Infections Are Sharply Down
first_paragraph: Coronavirus infections have dropped sharply in Paris following a strict two-month lockdown and a growing contact tracing effort, health officials say, and they have remained in check since the city began a halting return to life nearly two weeks ago.

title: Future of Shakespeare’s Globe Theater Is Threatened by Lockdown
first_paragraph: Shakespeare’s Globe, a celebrated institution in London that showcases some of the world’s most recognizable stage plays, is in danger of permanently closing if it does not receive emergency funding to help make up for revenue it has lost during the coronavirus lockdown.

title: In China’s Crisis, Xi Sees a Crucible to Strengthen His Rule
